name: Trove
description: Grab your friends, hone your blades, and set off for adventure in Trove, the ultimate action MMO!
minimum_requirements: OS: Vista 32-bit Service Pack 2 Processor: Intel Core i5-2XXX @ 2.0GHz / AMD Phenom II X4 @ 2.6GHz Memory: 1 GB RAM Graphics: Intel HD Graphics 3000 or better DirectX: Version 10 Network: Broadband Internet connection Storage: 1 GB available space Additional Notes: Graphics driver: OpenGL 3.2 or DirectX 10.0

reviews.review_text: The dev team has got to be one of the most pants-embedded-in-skull backwards i've ever seen in terms of relating to their player base. If you're not one of the VIP-lister big names, you might as well not exist. If you are one of them, prepare to have the game rebalanced around your experience and given lavish rewards constantly just for being teacher's pet. I'm not exaggerating on this one - they recently as of the time of writing (05/01/2016) introduced Contests, where whoever has the most score in X category gets some pretty good prizes at the end of the week. Sounds fun? Well too bad this dev team are like fun mosquitos, because they managed to royally heck it up - mastery is a static statistic that can only possibly go up and catalogues how much stuff you've collected in the game. So those who already have everything get even more stuff, and those who are starting out get the finger. On that statement, i'm once again not exaggerating - one of the first weekly contests was akin to 'how many dungeons can you clear'. This resulted in hordes of high-end players descending upon the lowest level worlds like a plague of jackass locusts and cleared all the dungeons in a crazed gluttonous frenzy that'd make the zerg themselves soil their carapace. Why is this bad? Because the new players couldn't get any levelling up done because all the dungeons had been one-shot by the high end turd brigade.  Now I know, you could put this one more on the community than the devs themselves. However, I don't believe for one second nobody internally didn't forsee this happening. Are you seriously going to tell me that a dev team which as far as i've seen consists of at least seven people (most likely quite a few more) didn't confer among themselves and think 'Hey, we should probably put some kind of limit on this!'? What are they paying these nimrods in, pocket lint?  You may be noticing a trend here - that new players get the shaft a lot, and that I use the phrase 'i'm not exaggerating' a lot. I'm having to throw in these disclaimers because as I type this myself there's still some itching, tickling feeling somewhere buried deep in my brain that tells me 'Come on, no one can possibly develop something this stupid.'. Oh they can. They can. Did I recall the nerfs to a whole bunch of stuff which has made the game harder than ever for new players to get into, at the profit of the highest-end dev suckup players? Let's list a few!  - Classes, formerly available for an ingame currency you get a small daily stipend of, are now pay-only. You can get five or so for free by jumping through some various hoops, but once you've done that you have to open your wallet and bend over, or leave. This wouldn't be so bad if some classes weren't outright gimped, so it's entirely possible for a new player to make five crappy picks and then just be stuck.  - Dragons, a form of personal progression that grant account-wide power, have been made harder and harder to get. Dragon coins, the ingame currency you need to unlock them, have been made untradeable so you've got to accumulate 300 per dragon all by your lonesome. How do you get them? Hourly challenges, where you've got 20 minutes to clear X amount of dungeons in a specific area... which you get bonuses for if you're in a high level world, and if you're using one of two classes randomly picked from all the currently existing classes. See how that's a problem when you're low level and don't have many classes unlocked? Well unlock all classes, and you ca- oh. Oh dear.  - Content expansions. The new expansion Mantle of Power just came out as of the time of writing, and jesu cristo crocodrillo. I'll get to the myriad of inherent problems with that in a moment. How does it affect new players? It affects them negatively because a bunch of options have been 're-balanced' (read: nerfed into oblivion) around the new high-end content. The knock on effects of this on new players seem to have been totally ignored - the players who already have few options other than 'grind more' and 'git gud'. Double damage emblems which grant you a buff that actually makes you able to kill stuff in a reasonable timeframe got nerfed twice - first the ingame currency cost was raised, and then it got reduced to lasting something like 3 seconds, down from around 7 or 8. Why? Well, because **** YOU, THAT'S WHY. BUY MORE OF OUR STUFF.  That's just three pointers. I could go on all day, which you're probably feeling like I have already at this point, though in all honesty spending an equal amount of time reading this or playing Trove seems like you'd feel more accomplished after reading this.  Now as I said, the new expansion really shows off how creative the dev teams are. A lot of end game players were complaining that all they really had to do once they got there was grind grind grind. Don't worry, Avarem and his team have you covered! With the new themed elemental worlds to explore, you can do the following: - Grind the same dungeons as before BUT ON THE SEA! - Grind the same dungeons as before BUT IN LAVA! - Grind the same dungeons as before BUT IN THE SKY! - Fight a zerg rush of boss monsters for a randomized prize that you can only get out of a chest if you brought a key that you can only get randomly from a box that randomly drops, the prize being a gem that you need to level up BUT there's a random chance of failing to level up and smashing the gem into a million bits but don't worry there's an item in our cash shop that can repair the gem and then you can break it again because you had the audacity to try and make progress but don't worry, BEND OVER PEASANT, IT'S WALLET TIME.  Then, there's gems. Ohhhhh boy. Okay. This one's going to take a bit of explaining for the layman's benefit, but at this point you've already read the 500 meters, why not go for the reading marathon? Reading is good for you! So pre-release in Trove the gear system was.. not great. Gear could only be improved so far, so it was possible to get a 'bad drop' which would have terrible stats you don't want and you'd be stuck with it unless you want to go find some other thing. If it was a high level drop with bad stats? Too bad for you, grind more. This was rather unpopular and was eventually replaced with the current system where any piece of gear can be forged all the way up from the lowest to the highest quality and you could re-roll the random stats. Get a cool-looking sword with bad stats on it? No problem, just get some crafting materials to muck with it a bit until you've got the stats you want on it and you're good.  Now gems, the new 'power yourself up' thing comes out... and they run off the old gear system they scrapped that nobody liked. What. Not only that, but you can't see all the stats on them from the get-go. You have to upgrade them at a not-at-all cheap cost (which can fail and smash the gem as previously stated), at which point you can despair at your wizard being equipped with a physical damage gem ALL ALONG, that you need to pay to remove from the slot. Doublewhat. I despair to think anyone in the dev team thought they were being clever with this. Folks didn't like it once, they ain't gonna like it a second time with a bit of window dressing on it, genius!  Wow, i've actually hit the character limit on reviews. Weird. Closing word: I looked up the lead dev's development history. He has worked exclusively on flops, and it shows here. This game had potential, but not with this jerkoff leading the show. Burn the fields, salt the earth, start over - there's not going to be any good gaming to be found here until Trion does that.  Also note the dev response doesn't really address anything set forth here. Good job!

I would NOT recommend anybody to play Trove, I used to enjoy playing Trove every day for over a year (through the Glyph launcher which doesn't add hours to your Steam before you ask) but the game has become a cesspit ever since they made the game disgustingly pay to win out of greed. A few of the people who manage Trove are very rude, greedy and not above lying to their playerbase to satisfy their own agenda.  I personally have seen management lie to thousands of people to make themselves look like the innocent people on a number of occasions, impossible to trust a company without morals.  I had to speak to 6 people to try and resolve a simple problem and in the end I spoke to the CEO who was rude, lied to me and even swore in his emails to me.  This game used to be good but now it's a solid 0/10, don't waste your time.  Btw, if you're going to comment something incredibly stupid before reading my entire review and realising that I've played this game for hundreds of days through the Glyph launcher which doesn't add hours to Steam then I'll just delete your comment as it's irrelevant.
I played for one hour..  and then i played for 19 hours straight  Edit: (i miss the time with my club) ): i don't play this really anymore..
What's the difference between Trove and Pay To Win? Who the hell even knows anymore

Don't be fooled by the hours on this profile, I've already commented with my 1k+ hours account, and wanted to add a negative review with this one.  Briefly summing up my previous negative review:  This game is:  1) WONDERFUL when you try it the first time, the colors will instantly mesmerize you. So will the game and it's 'nice' rewards you get when you achieve the first few levels.  But then, you think Pokemon go's one big grind? You think levelling up to level 30 on lol is one big grind? You think that levelling up to rank 2 to play matchmaking on csgo is one big grind?  Boy you're in for a treat.  Mastering to level 300 - in this game. That's a ♥♥♥♥ing grind.  and check the market. Look at the game. Does it look like a hardcore action game to you?  No. It's a kids game.  Trionworlds. Thieves, scoundrels and dirty moneymakers.  Sure, every company's aim to make money. But these guys?  'Here's a package that's 50$ to get you one pixelated dragon that gains you 1 'mastery' - level. and some chests where the rng's so ♥♥♥♥ you're going to get the 5$ package's items.'  Oh, did I mention it's a kids game?  This game's cancer, but it used to be amazing. Trionworlds created a beautiful child only to raise it into a disgusting person.  No other way to say it! I def recommend to try it out, then come back and give my review a thumbs up! :) glhf

Now as you can see I have played this game for 58 hours, so thats nearly 2 and a half days of my life that I invested in this game, It was the perfect storm of fetures that would attract most peoples attention such as an endless dungeon crawl that can be done with strangers and friends alike, a Diablo style dungeon crawl aswel, a basic yet good building system that allows you to build in greifer proof plots dotted around the landscape, a rather useful yet dull crafting system which seemed to be 'mix X with Y and try to get the highest stats' and a wide array of classes to play as ranger from classic rpg classes such as Knighs, Rangers and Wizards going all the way to Cyborg Ninjas, Candy Barbarians and even badass Dragon Pyromancers and plenty of cosmetic items that can be use as skins for better yet uglier items. So me and my friends decided to give it a go and befor we knew it we where playing in high Uber difficuties and clearing shadow dungeons by our selves, then we stopped playing for a while and came back only to realize that all the items which we could have easily bought with the mass amounts of cubits wher made that you could only buy them with the premium currency, and then the devs make weak responses to critisism like 'you can still find the items ingame, the currency isfor people who dont have the time' which is a horrible excuse made by plenty of these 'free 2 play' devs who dont know how to implement their premium currency right, DE does it right by making the items obtainable by both means in Warframe and easily too. So play this if you feel like it I just know that anyone who understands f2p games would understand the intising updates, but the ultimate backstab once the devs have a high enough fan base and feel like they can get away with anything

Let me start out by saying, this game USED to be good. It was nice that there wasnt too much grinding, it was great and intuitive that your items were what mostly depended on your power and level, not just exp. Let me now tell you what RUINED this once new and explosive game. (BTW if you are a new player I DO NOT RECOMMEND this game. Maybe play it for the experience because when you get to at least u4 and gem RNG you'll want to end your life.)   PVP  Holy guacamole dont even get me started on Class Gem Pirate Captain and darn tooting Ice Sage with instant ability cooldown. At first, I much enjoyed ruining peoples lives as an ice sage. I thought it was hilarious. Then I came across teams with 2-3 ice sages and wanted to end my futile existance. I've quit PVP because of one class. I dont find it fun to enrage people with freezing anymore because I now know what it's like to be on the butt end. Sorry to all whom I froze because I lost all chill (pun intended) when it happened to me.  GEMS and POWER RANK  Want to know how to increase power rank or get to u9? The answer is gems. It used to be farming a bit and upgrading gear, but now your shadow 5 and radiant gear is barely HALF of your Power Rank. This makes me sad. What's even worse is that the RNG on gems is totally freaking ridiculous. A shadow gem (better than relic/resplendant) can have MUCH WORSE stats than a Relic/Resplendant can. Sure, it MIGHT (that is a very very unassured might) have better Power Rank, but still, you'll have to GRIND and GRIND for Gem Dust to upgrade gems just so you can upgrade more to get a tiny bit more Power Rank. This game didnt used to be grinding. It was only softcore farming. RIP all players trying to get over 1200 PR in a short time.  NEW PLAYERS  There arent any. If you're a new player then congrats. You looked at this game and probably said 'This looks like a cute little softcore RPG! I'll try it out!'. I'm so sorry pal. Trove is now a HARDCORE GRINDING RPG THAT ONLY LOOKS CUTE. ON THE INSIDE TRION IS SECRETLY THE GOSH DARN ILLUMINATI (whose servers are on Pluto btw. Trion is a Plutonian name is you didnt know) AND THEY WANT YOU TO PLAY AND PAY AND SPEND ALL YOUR CASH ON GEMS SO YOU CAN HOPE YOU GET GOOD ONES BUT THEN DONT AND HAVE TO PAY TO WIN ALL OVER AGAIN!!!!!!!!!!!!   Dear Trion, Dude. What the hoot.  P.S. You've taken a good juicy pinapple of a game, eaten it and then ♥♥♥♥ it out and left it to rot. Tbh, you're almost as bad a Kabam (My lord that was harsh...)   From, An extremely angry player whose spent too much time and money on it >:(  GET GUD TRION AND STOP LEECHING THE POPULOUS' CASH FLOW

The game has a lot of potential, but the queue is killing me. Everything seems to be alright now, no queue anymore, and the games keeps me glued to my chair. Good job, and have fun playing you fellas. My dream is now complete, I have been killed with a candycane. 10/10 would play again.

Trove isn't bad per se, it just gets boring and repetitive really fast.  Yes, it's quirky, humorous, colorful & generally oozing a positive vibe. Yes, there is strong community aspect & some user created content can be awe inspiring. Yes, there are certain really nice game mechanics, like for example your cornerstone - a house of your own that you build & that you can place & relocate everywhere you want with a single button press. Also the music can be dreamy (Neon City <3).  Basically it's good to goof around for a bit, log in daily for a short while and log off. But as far as progression goes it requires a lot of time and repetition. Whether it's crafting, building, unlocking new classes or raising your mastery level - it all takes insane amounts of mats/currency & grind.   Sure the maps and dungeons are randomly generated. Sure, the dungeon design is quite fresh and can be very imaginative (or confusing ;). Sure, there are plenty of funny classes to choose from. But most dungeons are short (find boss, kill boss, take loot, get out) and sooner rather than later you learn all the design patterns and the novelty that came with it wears off (especially when you need to farm bajilion of them). Classes are very basic: main attacks - left click & right click, and 2 additional skills only. And they also take long to unlock, so if you happen to pick one that doesn't suit you, you'll struggle on your way to unlocking the next. And even if you pick a fun one, after a while you'll get bored with it, because there is only one way to play a certain class, and you'll be repeating the same combat pattern over and over.  Crafting is done via stations. Each station contains a list of items/things/portals/mounts/stuff you can make. To be able to craft other things, you need to craft other stations. You end up with several of them placed in your cornerstone and have to remember which allows you to make what (or go through them & all the lists top to bottom, every single time you're trying to make a specific item). Not the most elegant of solutions. Anyway, for some things you'll need hundreds (if not thousands) of materials, that you can obtain by harvesting in the world (right click in build mode, that you can switch to anytime) or by killing stuff, completing dungeons and disassembling loot in via the loot collector. Also some crafting branches you have to level up by making hundreds of items, before you're allowed to make anything decent.   Building requires a lot of blocks as well (especially larger guild projects), but actually the building part is the least obnoxious aspect of Trove and doesn't take any extra effort than say Minecraft.  Because of all the things mentioned above you'll find yourself either running around & right clicking (=collecting) materials from the game world for prolonged periods of time or doing those fast dungeons ad infinitum. Once in a while you'll place your cornerstone in order to maybe craft or build something, just to be reminded of how much stuff you still need to obtain.  Like I said, Trove is good to log in once in a while, play around & log out (especially if you don't care about achieving anything specific). It's a pretty neat time waster if you have no games to play or just don't feel like doing anything else. Unfortunately I have a whole backlog of games I'd rather be playing over this and I'm not blessed with overabundance of time to kill, so I won't be playing Trove anymore.

First off this is from a player who has spent 80+ hours playing. Would be more if this recent update didn't completely destroy progression.  Pros: Fun engaging combat Many weapons,armor,and various other things to collect. Multiple biomes with unique bosses.  Cons: Dispite it saying free,this is a pay2win game through and through. With this most recent update (2/9/2016) they've made it so that in order to access areas of the game,you need to grind weeks if not months into obtaining items that all usually have the same stats so this means obtaining useless trash in large quantitites just to advance in the game. This makes progressing incredibly tedious and incredibly time consuming with the only reward being a couple ticks of points. A recent update has made changing classes cost real money. You like that barbarian class? I hope you have a fat wallet. They've made obtaining classes only obtainable through real money and a in game marketplace. Just yesterday I was able to unlock any class with little effort but due to them locking off our ability to unlock classes this way you're either forced to spend real money or buy incredibly overprice and inflated items that you might as well just spend real money on because they're ridiculously expensive.  Game cliant crashes all the time,bugs plague the game,clipping through walls and floors is normal,huge amounts of lag on monster computers is pretty normal too.   Yesterday I would have recommended this game but today after the newest game changes I would never recommend this game to anyone.
get to level 20, then they tell you you need to pay 15 dollars to get to level 30

This game has great potential, but sadly the devs aren't noticing that. The game has horrible servers which result in hooribly laggy gameplay due to server faults and very high ping even in low demand zones. The in-game store gives you the option to 'pay to win' becuase you can get high level or buy things you can get without paying in the game. Trove doesn't reward high level players in chat or in gameplay besides high mastery levels for yellow name in chat. The updates of the game are also bad, every 'weekly patch' the developers 'add' or 'fix' something but most of the time the problems don't get fixed until a few days later or sometimes aren't even fixed, also the updates or patches often end up causing more glitches or problems in the game then there was before it. I played trove for a year and a half, I don't reccomend this game at all. STAY AWAY FROM IT!!

A very fun game with absolutely awful servers. Like seriously, this is the laggiest game I have ever personally played. It's also basically annoying children simulator 2016. 'how do u find ore' 'how do i ride a horse' 'can someone invite me to their club pls' 'how do i breathe' Yep. Still giving it a positive review. Despite all this, I seem to have fun.

Like many other users said, this game used to be good. It was ok a few months ago and I recommended this game. But now, the in game market has gone to complete ♥♥♥♥!  I said the game was ok because everything that needed premium currency(credits) to buy could have been bought on the community market of the game for a somewhat fair price. Class coins were available for 20,000 flux (non-premium currency?) which might seem like a lot, but it isn't. It's not too hard to farm 20k flux if you know what you're doing. I used to craft a mount by growing and harvesting the required plants. It sold for about 4000-8000 flux and I could make two of those a day. Also doing the hourly events (forgot what they are called haven't played in a while) and beating the shadow tower gave a lot items which can be turned into flux.  I saw the price of class coins in the market double during my 190 hours in the game. They were going for 40k however, I was still able to farm the required amount, it just took twice as long. It wasn't a deal breaker. Then I got tired of the game and quit playing for a few months because it got kind of boring. Too much grinding later on in the game.  I logged in after a few months and now the class coin is worth 200,000 flux! That is ridiculous! I'd be better off buying the classes from the store for over 1000 credits which is at least $10. It's $10 only if you buy the credits seprately. No one playing the game will recommend that though, because the packs, which costs more, is a much better deal.  That is just one problem with the game. As other reviews have mentioned, the grinding is terrible. Especially late game when you need the absolute best gear to survive. Getting the best gear with the best stats for your class is a gamble! I haven't played in a while so I can't explain that part very well but the other reviewers have.  This is a great game if you don't mind spending a lot of money on it. Crafting is fun. Building your own house is fun. Fighting bosses with your friends is fun. Stupid amounts of grinding is not.

Being a breath of fresh air in the voxel style of games, Trove varies from it's similar titles in ways that are appeasing to the eye and the community. The first of it's kind aside from Cube World, Trove is a massive RPG that allows you the freedom to customize the way you play, the way your character looks, and your all-around experience of the game. Trove has improved greatly since its early days in Closed Beta. The course of the game is far more easy to understand, as you now have objectives pointing you in the direction of your journey.  One of the best parts of Trove is that it is not Cash Shop heavy, and most things can be bought with the in-game currency that is given to you by killing enemys completing quests. Mounts can be found as loot throughout the game, but can also be bought at a reasonable price. Companions, which are pets that will follow you around and attack enemies with you, can be found in the game as loot as well, but you can also buy them in the cash shop.  Trion Worlds did a great job on Trove's 'guild' mechanic. Instead of joining a guild full of players, you can join something called a 'Club', which has it's own world and chat for you and your friends to have fun with.  Trove's character customization is also one that deserves to be a lesson to other MMORPG's. You don't have to pay premium OR in-game currency to change the way your character looks. So if you don't like your character's appearance, or you simply want to try something new, it is at no cost to you whatsoever.  The community is a huge part of the Trove world. Hats and masks for you to wear are mostly made by the community themselves, which can be picked up. Credit is of course given to the person who made the face, and they come up with some pretty creative names for the items.  If you don't like the way your class plays out, or you simply just want to try your hand at a different class, don't worry. You can pay premium or in-game currency to change your class. Don't like the way the Neon Ninja looks, and want to try your hand at another one, the choice is yours for a small price.  Do I recommend this game? Of course, it's a great game with an ever-evolving community with very active developers who have been very calm during this hectic launch.  I give it a 9/10

I try to keep it short.  This review comes from a maxed out player, who began shortly after the beta was finished. I had nearly anything archieved (Mounts, Dragon, Allies, Styles, Costumes) and had the best Equipment aswell as the money to buy everything i wanted. (I have WAY more hours on the Glyph launcher.)  I loved this game, I really did.  There was no marketplace so it was nice to trade. You were able to archieve things in a reasonable time. The classes were able to be bought with currecncy you gained for logging in daily, which I think was a fair deal. The only thing you needed to pay for with real money was (like in many other games) cosmetics ,things which made things easier for you and some premium mounts which were avaible also from time to time for free-players.  I played this game without spending any penny and in the end i don´t regret. The greedy dudes from Trion rolled out like 3 patches which totally destroyed the game, its currency and they lost many of their members.  Let me briefly give you an insight of what they did:  -There are 12 Classes   earlier: all avaible after some period of time  now: 5 Classes for free rest needs to be bought with real money (or traded via Ingame-Market, but still needs to be bought from someone). -Added a Power-Level which made it ridiculous hard for newbies to get a foot on the endgame content. -Dragons which were able to be 'collected' durring a specific time and which have a serious impact on you Power-Level were now hidden behind a freaking hard grind time earlier: 1 Dragon like 1-2 Weeks of time needed the additional earning could be sold to other players which were to lazy to do the missions now: 1 Dragon like 8 Weeks of time needed and less additional stuff gained to sell (which is bad for economy) Quote: 'New, limited time, $100 Credit Pack is now on the store. This pack contains $100 worth of Credits and a bonus tradable Golden Lunar New Year Egg, which immediately hatches Selene, the Celestial Storm, with no additional materials required!' -Thats the way grind it or buy it  This act of total contempt of the community made me giveaway all of my stuff, say goodbye to everyone i had known in this game, uninstall the game and write trion what i thought about the changes. Unfortunately they didnt care and kept going with this monkey business.   My conclusion:  If you are able to get a time travel machine i totally recommend you to play the game until there will be a patch name 'Monkey Business'. If you are a ULTRA tryhard and you like masochistical grinding this game is woth a try. But if you like a nice ballenced, fair F2P game with kind devs this game is the wrong attempt. ~ Love you Trion :*, never see you again

Great game, really is.  I've been playing this game nonstop, it's ridiculous.  PROS: -Community is incredibly helpful from what I've seen. You can ask pretty much anything in the global chat, or certain 'groups' you can join, and you'll get a response really quickly. I'd recommend watching some streamers and see what their requirements are of joining their group. Usually very big groups with helpful people. -Easy to play with friends, you can use your friends list to teleport to your friends easily. Cooldown time can be annoying, but is necessary. -The interactiveness in general is AMAZING! Like you can be typing while loading a new map/area, and when the map loads, your chat is still there. Some games just close your chat which can be very annoying. Also, you can have your inventory open with chat, so you can transfer names of objects easily. Overall, very interactive interface. -Unique 3 tier leveling system, base level, armour level, and mastery level. Very cool system. -A lot of different classes with different play styles and skills. Allows for anyone to find the class that best fits them. -Forums where they post updates and reasons behind downtime and what not. Also posts when the servers are back up. -A bunch of streamers, where you can win giveaways and what not. Good for starting players, and more experienced players. Can never say no to giveaways! -Trove is very appreciative of any content creators. Anyone who designs an object gets like 200 copies of that object, and can give them away or make a ton of oney off of it. Regardless, really nice of Trion Worlds for doing that.  There are a lot more things, I just don't want to keep on writing. Overall, great game. Now, for some cons.  CONS: -Downtime downtime downtime... so much of it. You really need to be patient with this game. They've had downtimes spaning 5 minutes, and downtimes spanning a full day. This game, when starting out. Was fun. Emphesis on the was. Starting out in this pay to win minecraft mod is amazingly painstaking. There are multiple classes, all in which, you can level up and put gear on. Only problem is those classes cost money now. You can only get free classes when you've gotten a certain point into the game. These points are referred to as mastery. You earn mastery by getting things such as weapons, dragons, mounts, and classes. Problem is. All of those things cost cold hard cash. Mounts can be bought or crafted. Crafting takes mastery, mastery takes money. Want a dragon? Spend money. Want a costume for the class you just bought for 10 dollars? Spend 20 dollars. Wish to get to a point in the game where you are having fun all the time? Not a chance. This game has some of the least satisfying gameplay you might ever see. Kill monsters, get loot. Fun the first 1000 times. If you had gotten this game in December of 2015. I'm pretty much an end game player at this point. Got the second best gear, because I didn't have to pay to get it. Got the coolest mounts and dragons, a class I love and friends I can play with. All these things simply do not make up for the pay to win garbage I sat through for 2 months playing.   I do fully respect Trion for making a game pay to win, though. In the end, a company has to make money, it all boils down to that. It's just a shame to see a promising game go down the drain. All in the course of 3 months.

Rest in Peace Trove. You were a great game, until the greed of your developers overwhelmed their will to make a game that awas fun for both veteran players and new players alike. Pros and cons of this game:  + Free to play  + Dungeons are easy to find, and doesn't rely on team effort unless you need to do it faster.  + Creating your own area and having it seen by people.  + Classes are simple and creative in that they provide different roles in the game. You can choose to be a sword wielding tank, a damage heavy character or a spell-toting dragon. (There are more characters)  + Family friendly (lol)  + Mounts, pets and wings provide smoother gameplay but doesn't make you overpowered damage wise. Most of these things are just pleasing to look at while defeating mobs.  + Questlines give you free 'Cubits' that you can spend in the shop for classes, emblems, and mounts.  - Gets grindy if you aren't spending the gameplay with people.  - Only two abilities for each class  - Long que timers which are still being worked on. I recommend to play this game with friends and if you have a couple of hours to destroy. GL 'TROVIANS'

There are positives for this game, and there are negatives. However, there are mostly negatives.   For one thing, the client Glyph. For those who haven't downloaded the game yet, the game downloads a client called Glyph, which has you sign up for an account. Don't know why it just doesn't use Steam, but whatever. However, the client has a lot of problems. Sometimes the client will refuse to load, other times the client freezes, and most commonly, the client will be SO SLOW. Another thing about the client is that it downloads updates for Trove. From my experiences, Steam is not the one that downloads it. This causes a serious issue sometimes.  Secondly, the camera, or really the fact that the level design goes against the camera. There are dungeons that you must explore, and in some of them, there are 'trampolines', which will launch you into the air. Some of these are essential to get to the boss. However, some of these are parkour, which is where the issue occurs. The camera will get extremely close to the block above you and will make your character take up the entire screen.  Another problem is the dungeon structure. Some dungeons will have several rooms that are filled with minions and one big room either above ground surrounded by a sphere or below the minion rooms. However, by taking advantage of the abilities that allow you to place and remove blocks (Which along with the world filled with cubes, was definetly not copied from anything mainstream  Cough Couch Minecraft Cough Cough , you can easily reach the boss without fighting any minion, which begs the question: 'Why bother?'  Two of the worst parts of this game are the help it provides you and the  GRINDING  . The game provides you with missions, which go along the lines of 'Use WASD, Go Through A Portal, Craft Something, Craft Something Else, Find Some Minerals, Craft Something Else, Defeat Some Dungeons,  GRIND , Craft Something Else,  GRIND ', and then it suddenly tells you to basically get 3000 currency. The biggest problem with this structure is the grinding. While I understand grinding is present in almost every RPG game, this game makes it so that it takes FOREVER. The other problem is the lack of details for literally everything. 'Oh, do you want to know what the hell gems are used for, or how to join a club, or how to ride your mount? Well, we don't have the budget to tell you how to do that with a linear tutorial, so we are going to wait until you look online or read each and every page from our How To Play section.' I spent so long wondering what gems were used for and how to use them, and I was consistantly taking a long time to beat monsters, and that was because the game never told me how to use gems. Once I equiped one and leveled it up with all 400 GEM DUST I HAD FROM NOT KNOWING HOW TO USE IT, my power rank skyrocketed by 60 levels, and I became unkillable. This leads into the final problem with this game, the overall difficulty. It's extremely easy. Once you know what the hell everything is thanks to online guides, the game becomes more of a chore. All you have to do is hold down the left mouse button and ocassionaly press the right mouse button, 1, 2, and q whenever your screen gets a red border. 'OH THE VARIETY'.   Now, I do realize that I am complaining a lot about a free game, but I will give it some credit, even though it might have been unintentional. This game doesn't require you to buy anything, or at least to my knowledge. Because the game is so easy, the game is not a 'Pay To Win' game, which is something that it does better than a mainstream full price game.  Cough Cough Call Of Duty Black Ops 3 Cough Cough . Overall, the game does have something going for it. If you're into grinding, bad camera angles, or you just want to play an easy game, this is a decent choice. Final Fantasy Fans, you might want to look elsewhere.

I can see this game being a fun free to play MMO at the start but I couldn't bring myself to actually like this game as I went through it.  Keywords = 'at the start'  Let me explain. This game is just a literal grindfest. You will do nothing but grinding the same dungeons over and over again in a portal to get different levels and get higher tiers of gear. Once you have done all of that, you will proceed to the next portal and do the exact same thing and then after that,you go to the next portal to do the same thing which makes the game really repetitive as well.  To counter the amount of grinding in the game (mostly by a few hours), you will need to pay the developers/publishers real life money which can come in amounts of £7,£15 and to even go as far as £80. Yes, £80 (Which is the highest amount I have seen so far but it probably goes higher than that). So if you want to save a few hours of grinding to get another class or healing item, be prepared to pay quite an amount of money.  There is no endgame. Once you have gotten to the uber 5/6 tier (Whatever the highest is) with the best tier of gear, there is literally nothing else to do after that. Well, there is Shadow Tower which is kinda like raid bosses but you will need to get keys to be able to get into the place which will takes hours/days to get or you can pay them money to get the keys faster. If you do manage to a get key for it, you will probably get killed in like 1 minute if unprepared and then since your key gets consumed, you will have to pay even more money or grind for another day just to get another one.  Customisation. Although this game has tons of weapon skins, hats and masks which make up for the actual lack of character customisation - There is literally nothing but hair, eye colour and skin type. That's it. No gender, no race, nothing.  The community. The community is what you would expect in an MMO like this; rubbish. In some cases of this, I have seen people calling other people anti-homosexual slurs, racial slurs or just general insults just because they don't like a certain part of the game or they don't like another game such as League of Legends and say that Dota 2 is better than it when it's just their opinion. I have also seen people trying to fish but then you have people come in the areas with massive boats to block the other player's sight so they can't tell whether a fish is hooked or not and then the players in boats keep shooting the cannons so the player's fishing can't hear the sound cue for the fish bite either. There are also tons of scammers in this game too which include fishy trades and then being kick straight after, people overpricing items which are probably worth nothing and even getting people to type in referal codes saying it will help them but it will only help the scammer get a mount.  Finally, there are no quests or NPCs... well, there are mobs in this game which don't really count as NPCs. There are no NPCs such as wandering travellers/merchants, no quest givers, nothing but mobs. There is no quest system either so no saving a village or shadowing or anything. Instead they put challenges in the game which can takes hours to complete (depending on what it is) which will earn you a currency called 'Cubits' which allow you to buy things in the ingame store such as classes or healing flasks because literally everything else in the store such as mounts, wings, chests and all that other stuff costs real money.  Although this game has a lot of negatives, there are a few positives too. Biomes. Biomes in this game are different areas you can explore which are different environments like snow, dragon peaks, isles with pirates, forest and even medieval highlands. All of these biomes have certain items in them that you can't get anywhere else such as gear, pets and crafting materials, and certain ores.  Another positive to this game (And probably the only other one) is the building/crafting mechanic. You have the complete freedom to build whatever you want in this game (providing it's in your cornerstone which is your buildable home, of course) so you can build a house, massive towers, massive male genitalia and whatnot. You can also get different colours such as green, black, blue... Screw it, the whole colour spectrum is at your disposal. You can also craft decorations such as 'gumball machines' (or whatever they're called over here in England), pool tables or you can even hang the heads of your enemies on the wall too. You will also be able to craft helpful items such as portals to get into different tier grindfests, different tools such as a forge to help improve your gear and other basic things in an MMO.  That's about it. If you're looking for an MMO which is nothing but a timewaster with the amount of building and grinding or if you are literally made out of money, this is the MMO for you. But if you are looking for and MMO with quests or an interesting story and whatnot, then there are plently of better MMOs out there and you should skip this one.  I could've been doing my college assignments instead of writing this review. 4/10.

Throughtout all the time I've spent on this game, I can honestly say that it was one of the funnest experiences I ever got from a video game, and an MMO at that. It reminded me of another game that I know called Cube World, which I was legitimately interested in for a LONG time. Having all this in mind, I played the game to it's full potential alongside my sister and a friend: leveled up, slayed hundreds of shadows, built a house, raided dungeons, and even created a Club (basically what a guild is called in Trove) straight from scratch, and made friends along the way as well. On occasion, the game would close down due to the scheduled updates and patches being implemented into the game. Most of them would fix up the game, while others changed the game a bit here and there and gave things more flavor.   However, after spending so much time playing the game consistently and noticing it's only aspect was raiding dungeons, the game grew boring with each passing day from that point onward. Don't get me wrong, the game is great and they are constantly adding new things into the game so it's still growing in my opinion, but this is one of those games where if you spend WAY too much time on, things become bland and the spark just isn't there anymore. As a final verdict, I'll have to say that you should play the game and see how things go for you. Just, you know, play it at a pace that won't cause you to become extremely bored and tired of it; that way, it'll be much more fun when you get on the next time.

Trove - A Voxel MMO RPG by Trion Worlds  Short version:  A building, exploring & collecting game best described as silly fun.  Long version:  I've been playing Trove for about 2 and a half months now. Its very fun a fun game but not without faults.  Building - This has improved recently but even before this was very capable and this shows. While permanent building is restricted to cornerstones (your own private house) and club worlds, the amount of creativity is astonishing. People have made some truly amazing club worlds. There is a club world full of music, others with boat & wing race courses and some truly awe inspiring creations.  Adventuring - There are no quests besides the tutorials designed to teach you the game. You just go out and find things to kill. Small lairs, huge dungeons and later on shadow arenas. Until you get towards the end game content (more on that later) its a very casual and relaxed game. While you dont form patries, working in groups is rewarding and allows you to push forward a little faster.  Collecting - As you progress through the game you earn mastery points. Mastery levels unlock various rewards (like wings at 20 and access to challenges at 30) with the untimate goal to reach max mastery (currently 200). Raising your mastery can be sped up a little with items from the shop but almost everything can be obtained in-game through work, trading or bought from the shop with in-game credits.  End game - End game currently is completing hourly challenges, shadow arenas and Uber 6 dungeons to get better gear and upgrade items. Challenges are admittedly a bit is a mess with huge zergs of adventurers rushing around a biome stripping it bare like a swarm of locusts. Its a mad rush to earn dragon caches but the best way to earn materials and resources required to upgrade gear.  Pay2Win & RNG - Is it Pay2Win? In a word, no. There is no 'win' in trove. Even when PvP is added this shouldnt change. You can buy a patron pass that gives more XP, extra jump but none of these give you any kind of real advantage. Trove contains a lot of RNG. Dragon caches, adventure boxes, chaos chests, miner's troves, shadow caches, nightmare boxes and radiant caches (all earned in different ways) are all RNG boxes and rarely drop good items. None require money to open and are mostly just a bit of fun with a chance to get a cool mount, pair of wings or something equally as fun.   {LINK REMOVED}  Referral link so I can earn a dragon :)

This game has it all! I will list only some of the amazing things about it.   Pro: +Free building (you can place blocks literally anywhere!) +Hack & Slash combat with actual aiming +A portable house +You can jump over 30 times +You can play any class on one character and switch between them at any time +You have a club world to build in with your friends +Dungeons are detailed and have tons of designs and wonderful structures +There are thousands of items and many of them are references to pop culture and video games. (Batman bow, Teemo hat from League of Legends, Fins sword from Aventure Time and many more) +The game is super kid friendly and even the global chat seems to be quite polite most of the time +You can teleport to friends at any time +The game can run on pretty much any machine +Tradeing is easy and fast +Crafting is simple, same as gardening +You can get cool mounts and wings for in game currency! So there isn't even a need to pay for anything!! +You get free Chaos Chest's every day, from which you can get ANYTHING, including Pay to Get mounts, wings, costumes, etc. +The graphics are smooth and colourful.  Con:  -The queue times are long as hell sometimes, but in my oppinion it's the best solution how to save the servers from frying and not make everyone in the game lag. -Since the game is free to play there will be way more hackers, but let's hope the devs can deal with that :)  Overall: 9/10  The game is amazing and one of the best new MMO's out there. Once they get enough servers it will be a 10/10. Play it with your friends and have a blast!

As someone with over 1000 hours into the game, I realised that the more I play it, the more disappointed I get. The forums are incredibly strict and voicing your true opinion could get you banned on them.   With each update, they change more things that they shouldn't and don't care that their ridiculous ideas will possibly upset almost the entire experienced playerbase. Everything is now heavily RNG-based, which is beyond frustrating at times. If you want to progress you have to farm hours upon hours, with a high risk that in the end, it was for nothing, as upgrading gems fails very easily.   For being in Open Beta since 2014, the game is still beyond unstable, and each patch has a high chance of breaking the game entirely or making it very hard to play.   The devs claim to listen to the community, but for me personally it seems that all they do is come up with purchaseable solutions, making this game really difficult to play or enjoy without spending real money on it. If you want to decently progress in this game, you either have to have A LOT of free time, or buy Patron.   I really don't agree with how the weekly contests happen, as everything they have implemented in them only benefit the people who have gotten very far in the game and funnelled loads of money into it.   The latest updates have forced me to give up this game and move on, because the feelings of frustration and disappointment were stronger than my attempt at having a good time on it.   But if you're into hours of mindless grinding, frustrating devs who only think of how else they can milk cash from their playerbase, getting banned on the forums for voicing your opinions and having your posts deleted, spending money just to notice some kind of progress or dealing with massive lag ALL THE TIME, then i guess this game could be for you.   10/10 super disappointing.

Trove is a bit-block game that is similar to Minecraft, but just like any other MMORPG out there. It still lacks that energy that will leave players hanging on and keep playing. Trove has expanded a lot since the pre-alpha stages, in terms of its UI, game mechanics, classes, and open-world generation. The character classes has adopted the same style as Firefall, where all the classes can be earned by collecting the Cubits (daily-earned currency) and redeeming them. If you're those who loves to collect the collectibles, maybe this game is good for you to continue in search of the items.  What's interesting behind the leveling system in Trove is that, the max Level that can be leveled is Level 20. But to move beyond Level 20, you need to obtain Shadow items, refining it, to further increase this capped level. Where maybe things starts to quite grinding as it goes further. Nevertheless it's not just about the leveling, but there is also Mastery system, where each items you collected or actions you have done in Trove accumulates into this system. So it is beneficial to focus on Mastery first.  Trove has a marvellous open-world generation, that you continue to explore the Uber-worlds. I'm sure none of the worlds are similiar in any sense, since it's a mega world with various biomes merged together. Besides fighting dungeon, you can also actively participate in the Club or Cornerstone, architectural building of blocks. Some of the creative worlds can be seen in forums, like Mario World or Pokemon's Pallet Town. Trove also been always very active in their server maintenance, every Tuesday. They have come out with numerous events and limited period items that allows players to hunt and collect these items.  For network wise, it is still playable for Asian players. Although you will experience a little bit of slow response in preloading of objects. Especially Trove sends objects in chunk that loads the next few segments of land, that is in your camera view. This is very adaptive, as Trove adopts the world generation feature. Similarly for dungeon when it comes to boss-battle, it is preloads it for just that instance, so don't worry about dying out.

My disclaimer: My hours played on Steam are not reflective of my actual in-game time. I installed from Trion's site last year, which will not show up here. If you average daily time X months, I would have in the ballpark of 800+ hours played. I loaded up the Steam version so I could post my review here.  Pre-level 20, the game is quite fun. Housing, crafting, exploring, and building will keep you occupied for hours and hours. It's the perfect game to play on those days when you are sick, and jacked up on cold meds. Casual, colorful, and something you can pick up and put down without much fuss.  After level 20 the game changes drastically. The Mantle of Power (MoP) update introduced a new gear system (Gems) that is entirely dependent on the Cash Shop, and a punishing degree of grind that affects experience gained, as well as items looted. Additionally, character progression is now measured in Power Rank, which is directly tied to Gems.  Before MoP, gear could be improved by using materials gained from breaking down looted drops and then using player made forges to upgrade quality and stats. It was a straightforward system, and as long as you had the materials you would upgrade your item on every combine.  Gems require materials as well, dust, which is gained from breaking down trash gems you don't need. However, rather than a guaranteed level increase when you click, you get a CHANCE for improvement. There is also a progress bar, which does not exist on regular gear. So, every time you click, you still burn materials but you are not guaranteed an incremental increase on the progress bar. On top of this, gems are designed to crack often. If that happens, you cannot improve your gem unless you repair it. This is where you discover the insidious design of MoP that requires you to use the Cash Shop.  Gems are designed to crack often. A Cash Shop item is the only thing that will fix that.  Gem upgrades are designed to fail, and take multiple attempts to fill a progress bar which represents one level. Gems have multiple levels, and I have seen some with 20-30. There are Cash Shop boosters that will give the CHANCE at an increase in progression, as well as other boosters that give a CHANCE at an entire level increase.  Addtionally, there is time gating on top of the high failure rate and high cracking rate. If you did not use boosters, your progress would stop on the first crack. If you only stopped your gem from cracking, or repaired it, you then have to face the horrendous requirement for materials (that you grind for) and the insane number of failures (with time gating) on the progression bar per level, every level.   For one gem, assuming you just used a booster to stop the cracking, it would take you MONTHS to level it. Currently, there are 9 gem slots. You do the math.  So, you need multiples of boosters that are only found in the Cash Shop, and your purchase does not guarantee that the item will work.  This ties in directly to how your character progresses, and what content you can enter. Power Rank (PR) increases as your gems are improved. Content is gated by a PR level requirement.   MoP was designed to grind progress to a molasses in January crawl. That is, unless you go to the Cash Shop..again, and again, and again. Paying real life money (for a chance) to improve your gear, and thus to allow you to access content that is otherwise gated, is the hallmark of Pay to Win. It is also gambling.  Consequently, the community has sharply deteriorated. People with common sense, who didn't want to be subjected to Trion's montetization schemes, left to greener pastures. The diehard fanboys now populate the forums, and make it their business to ridicule and shut down people that are critical of what Trove has become.   I simply cannot recommend Trove to new players. 6 months ago? Sure. Now? Don't even bother. They've taken a page from Runes of Magic horrible monetization tactics and integrated it into this game, ruining what was once a really amazing experience and community.  Game Development: 3/10  - There hasn't been any resources put into building and crafting since launch. No new recipes. No new materials. No new blocks. This game was marketed as a creative, sandboxy, building game and they've utterly abandoned their core principles in favor of cash grab Cash Shop re-skins and RNG loot boxes.  Customer Service: 3/10   - Copy paste answers, or outright incompetance.  Community: 5/10  - unhelpful in-game chat. Official forums are run by fanboys. Some good guilds remain, but most of the decent people have left for other games. Spammers and trolls fill the chat.   Game Devs: 2/10  - Game took a sharp turn for the worse at the beginning of 2016. Completely unresponsive to community feedback. Lack of real game development outside of loot boxes and Cash Shop items.  Cash Shop: 2/10  - Some cosmetics, and inventory expanders. Rest of it gives in-game advantage by giving Mastery points (which in turn give bonuses that affect gameplay). Gem Boosters are Cash Shop only, and are explained above.  Game Stability: 4/10  - Better than 5 months ago, but still unstable. Unexpected crashes and horrendous lag at times. Rubberbanding. Very common complaint that the Devs have acknowledged is a problem on their end, but they seem unable to fix even at this point.  Overall: 4/10  - Score would have been 8/10 half a year ago. Recent and ongoing updates create more and more dependence on using the Cash Shop. Cash Shop items give in-game advantages, and are required to advance character progression.

11 days and 74 hours later, I finally can review this game and just how awesome it can be. Sure, it has it's moments with downtimes and queues, but the game underneath the skin is fascinating. The combination of the graphic style and gameplay melds together perfectly, and the exploration and combat both fitting together well. If you don't have any idea what games like this are like, but are feeling like you're missing adventure, try this game. Same can be said for vice versa. Hate adventure, but love voxel games, try it out.   I've loved every step of it, though the downtimes are extensive, I know that it's for the greater good and soon I'll be able to be online again. Thanks Trion, you've created a great gem.

At first, I gave this game a great review. After all, I spent about 10 hours in the game (my Steam hours are misleading, I don't like to run the game through Steam).  The first part of the game was extremely fun. Finding all the new items was very thrilling, and going into big dungeons was always challenging and fun, especially with friends.  It was also fun to build up my house and make my items stronger.  But after about 10 hours of gameplay, the game went from one of the best games I've ever played to one of the most boring.  Why is the game boring? Because you do the same thing over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over and over again. You only ever get 3 special abilities and you never get better combos as you level up. With my class, the gunslinger, all you ever have to do is: Jump. Attack. Jump. Attack. Jump. Attack. The other classes I've used aren't much better.  The bosses are quite stupid, and are quite low-quality for today's standards of RPG games. I've played multiple Final Fantasy games, and I know what a smart boss is like. All the enemies in this game are so stupid... all they ever do is just rush at you.  This game also suffers from a large lack of content, though that is an easy fix. However, they cannot fix the lack of veriety in the game. It suffers the same problem that vanilla Minecraft does: you do the same thing over and over again, and it gets quite boring.  The first part of the game and the overall concept of the game gets a 9/10.  After about 10 hours of gameplay, I give it a 5/10 for being really boring after a while.

TLDR: You can farm in this game for hours and make 0 progress. Which is bad game design in my opinion.  Ok so lets begin. Trove is a good concept of a game. I really liked it at the start actually. What really makes this game completely suck is the gem system that was implemented in the Mantle of Power update. See you can play and have fun progressing until you get to the last stage of the game which is Uber 9. Then the gems you have actually matter then. Which is the problem. -.- The RNG in this game is worse than any game I have ever played. Not only do you get random stats when farming gems, but even if you happen to get the right stats it will most likely still not be a good gem. Gems range from 0 to 3 stars at level 1. 3 stars being the best obviously. This might sound confusing but you see the amount of stars you have at level 1 dictate wether the gem is good or not. If that sounds stupid that's because it is. Also when it comes to farming stellar gems in Uber 9 you will most likely not get the stellar gem until you open enough boxes. You can open 70 boxes to get a gaurunteed stellar or 35 if you have patron. Which is also ridiculous. The point I'm making is that you can basically farm forever and get nowhere at all. Especially without patron. I don't recommend this game and I won't recommend this game until the gem system is changed.

If you're looking for a positive review, then you're in the wrong place, HOWEVER, if you're here for a tremendous chicken Stir Fry recipe, THEN LOOK NO FURTHER!  - Serves 4 - 10 mins to prepare and 10 mins to cook - 325 calories / serving - Healthy  INGREDIENTS:  - 1 orange, zested and juiced - 2tbsp soy sauce - 2tbsp sesame oil - 250g (8oz) tender stem broccoli - 5cm (2in) piece root ginger - 1tbsp sunflower oil - 1 garlic clove, finely sliced - 1 red pepper, deseeded and thinly sliced - 150g Straight To Wok Noodles - 400g (13oz) chicken fillet, cut into thin slices  METHOD  Step 1 - Mix together the orange zest and juice, soy sauce and sesame oil and set aside.  Step 2 - Blanch the broccoli in boiling water for 2 minutes, then drain well and set aside.  Step 3 - Finely shred the ginger. Then heat a large frying pan or wok, add the sunflower oil, heat it until sizzling, and fry the ginger till it's crisp.  Step 4 - When it's done, remove with a slotted spoon. Add the chicken and garlic, and stir-fry until just browned. Remove the meat using a slotted spoon and set aside.  Step 5 - Add the red pepper and broccoli and stir-fry for around 2-3 minutes until it's just tender. Add the soy sauce mixture, bring it to the boil then return the chicken to the pan and heat through. Serve with noodles.

Truth be told, I really liked this game. If you haven't already guessed by the amount of hours I've put into this thing, I've been with this game since the early days, when everyone started as the knight by default, and you didn't need to use credits (currency bought with real money) just to buy other classes. Sure you'd get the occasional class coin to unlock another one for free, but at this point in time it's not very friendly to new players that have the misfortune of wanting to start playing the game in this current meta of what's basically pay to win. Now I know I'm probably not the only one who's complaining about 'the good old days', but seriously, why are the other classes barred off with real money currency? I can understand skins, and even those 'patron bonuses', but I just think it's dumb to bar off new characters with this monetary wall.   I still occasionally visit because of the time (and sadly, money) that I've thrown into this game, but I can't play it as fervently as I used to, cause mmo's are mostly meant to play with friends, and the pay to win model puts a lot of them off. I realize this was less about gameplay and more of a complaint about the company's business choices, but honestly I don't think I could say anything about the game itself that'll convince anyone to look past the pay-to-win model. Maybe if they decide to go back on the money-centric game ideals, I'll boot the thing back up and dive in again. But as of time of writing, I can't recommend the thing.

I love the game itself, such an amazing feel for adventure, something that i have not felt in a game since first playing Minecraft or Terraria, there are many different types of dungeons which dont hold much challenge if you have the right equipment to jump past them, i find this rather disappointing as i expected challenging and dangerous tasks to complete them rather then ones where you can pretty much just warp to the final boss, although later level dungeons are harder they do not show much improvement other then monsters doing more damage and getting better loot. The game itself is a somewhat frustrating grind for either ores or flux which would seem to be the two things needed most to progress later on, the building feature is very interesting as well, being able to create wide lengths of blocks at once but at the same time rather twitchy and frustrating to get used to as i find myself placing blocks through walls or even behind me. The biggest and most annoying problem with the game is the logging in Queue time, i have heard this was fixed but i see very little improvement and i find myself waiting in a 10 minutes remaining window for more then an hour even counting how long it took. I understand the creators are still working out some of its issues and trying to fix as much as they can so i won't hold it against them due to them creating one of the most popular games to just recently hit Steam and perhaps were not expecting it to grow with such speed. All flaws aside, Trove is a fantastic game and i would strongly recommend it to many players, i give this game a ''7 / 10'' for its ability to keep me playing even past its flaws.

If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.  Ingredients: 1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter 2. 1/2 cup white sugar 3. 1/2 cup brown sugar 4. 1/4 cup water 5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon 6. 1 pinch salt 7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced 8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie   Directions: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C). 2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside. 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices. 4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal. 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust. 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.  Eat.

I've been playing Trove for quite a while now, so i'm a bit of an experienced player. This game is probably one of the best games i've run accross, here is what I think.  Pros:  Definitly is a great MMO-RPG What I mean is, the 'role playing game' is important and without a team after level 12 you WILL die. A LOT. The 'mmo' part, it has an AMAZING community, one of the best i've seen in any game. Great class veriety. Hey, thats always important. You can edit your looks anytime, for free! I'ts growing SUPER quick! I've noticed so many new people through the week. (and their usually advanced players) There are a lot more, but that will take a bit long and its all about the crafting system. Also, best of all its not pay to progress or be OP. IT'S ALL FREE TO PLAY! Well 99% of it.  Cons: The building is dreadful. The way to build your cornerstone (little plot you own) is hard and frustrating for everyone that I have met who owns this game. They released it today, that means 'new people!' but sadly, not only are there new people but, come trollers, hackers, and giant noobies to the MMORPG genre. I havn't encountered hackers yet but, i'm sure I will.  Other then that it's a great game and suggest you to check it out if you havn't, just give it some time.  ps. don't listen to my hours I have a lot more then that.

Developers refuse to even acknowledge that their network infrastructure (and servers) are so bad that they're losing players because of it.  When this game came out on Steam it was peaking at almost 70k players  daily . It was in the top 3 played games for almost a month. Having network/server issues in that situation is understandable, because it wasn't expected to explode in popularity the way it did. After dozens of 'improvements & upgrades' to their servers, netcode, databases, etc., the game is still painful to try and play today.  For reference, today, a Friday, had a peak of 17.8k players on Steam. Far cry from almost 70k, no? And somehow, despite all these improvements, the servers are going down almost daily. If they aren't down, the latency is so bad that you 'rubberband' so badly at times that it gets you killed, or disconnected from the server during VERY bad times. (Like the new end-game content they released instead of addressing server issues!)  Aside from the stability issues, the economy in this game is absolutely boned. The latest content update that brought the newest class, the Lunar Lancer, destroyed the economy in a massive way. Not only did it make end-game crafting materials harder to get (which was fine, honestly), which caused them to rise in price as expected... they also destroyed your ability to gain the currency to buy said items!   Long story short, this game is currently  NOT  worth your time. Until Trion fixes at least the network stability, just pass this up unless you want to pull all your hair out.

So as you can see, I have many hours logged on Trove now and here is my quick review of what to expect...  Pros: - The combat is very fast-paced and fun - The amount of character customization is insane! - The cornerstone system (basically a moving house you design) is both brilliant and fun to build - Tons of unique biomes, dungeons, enemies, and bosses - Way too many props and block types to possibly get bored building - Good social system with friends lists and clubs - Not PAY-TO-WIN  Cons: - Difficult to solo some of the higher level areas (but way fun with a group) - Sometimes gets a little repetitive  - Difficult to find some of the needed crafting materials - Currently no PvP (will be added in future according to devs) - Some shop items take A TON of in-game currency to purchase  Also a note: Currently they have bad queue times to log into the server, which is full of new players from Steam. The devs have already released server patches to help with the issue, and are constatly adding new hardware, but until the flow of new players settles down a bit, expect to be waiting a while to log in (sometimes half an hour). Once you are on though, the servers are smooth and stable.   Overall I highly recommend this game. It is fun, especially with a group, and it has loads of content to use with more coming all the time. Feel free to add me on Trove (player name: jackobuddy) and happy building!!!

Though the building is slightly bland, not as many options as I'd like for colours of blocks but I expect that to change aswell with time. There really is no PTW (Pay To Win) involved but if you wish you can use money to acuire cosmetic items and a few gameplay items  All in all very fun, and if you feel as if something else should be in game you can reccomend it to the developers

Trove is just... amazing. The unique characters with varying playstyles and difficulty levels, the addictive, charming gameplay and stunning, gorgeous yet simple, low end graphics make Trove one of my all time favourites. It's hard to believe that this masterpiece is indev. And heck, it's absolutely FREE! Sure, there are DLC's, and yes, they are overpriced, but do you really need to buy them? I think every user on steam should at least give this game a try. However, the servers are chock full most of the time, so don't be suprised if you have to wait to get in. But, if they are that full, then Trove is obviously good. Other than that, it's great!  My final verdict:  Pros: Addictive, simple and charming gameplay. Trove is a great little MMO that takes what was great about Minecraft and Terraria and expands on it. Trove is a some-what sandbox/dungeon crawler game that does not have any kind of story but encourages exploration. I spent hours on the beta before it hit Steam. Trove let's you build your own home/base with a ton of options in a nice sudo-8bit voxel style. You can explore dungeons, go on mini raids, sail on the ocean and fight pirates, fly, and much more. It is a free game with an in game store, but nothing in there utterly breaks the game experience. The store has some cosmetics with the same stats as anything in the game. There is a nice selection of classes in Trove with more being added fairly often that shake up the playing experince from something like Minecraft. Each class has it's own skills and more are unlocked as you level that class up. The classes can be swapped on the fly all on the same character, so if you don't like the feel of a certain class you can always swap with no harm! The combat system is simple but smooth and fun. There is something for the more casual players in this game of making a nice home, and having some fun exploring with friends, and then some nice end game dungeons for a little more devoted player, along with rare mounts to craft/collect. The game also encourages playing with others as you share loot and 'glim' or gold income. A very funny game to play with some friends. With a development team that is very social with it's community I can only highly recommend this little gem. 9/10.

Downloaded the game Saturday evening. Queue says '1000+ player wait time 40 minutes.' Naturally I think this is some sort of mistake or bug, but after some Googling I realize that nope, this game is just that popular.  Okay. So I wait 30 or so minutes, then the launcher says I am disconnected. Turns out it was unplanned server maintenence for 2+ hours. I just went to bed.  I woke up at 5 AM local time, tried to log on. 30 min queue, disconnect, retry. Finally was able to log in and do a tutorial which made the game seem colorful and fun, but after I killed the very first mob the game asked me to press H to warp to the hub and crashed.   Since then I haven't been able to log in because you get disconnected from the queue before you can ever try and play. This game LOOKs interesting and I want to play, but I simply CAN'T, because the devs do not have proper infrastructure.  I'll consider re-reviewing this game if I am ever _actually able to play it_. Steam as you can see records 5.5 hours of the game running on my computer but I was only in-game for <5 minutes. This is completely unacceptable.

I would not recommend this game without doing some hard research beforehand. If you choose a class you don't like, tough luck, you'll have to stick with it or grab a class change token or the alternative, just make a new account! There are no multiple characters per account and you have no option of deleting characters.   The controls also feel weird: they aren't clunky, but they aren't smooth either. The combat feels transparent and there is no real substance to your attacks. The way the UI has been designed is off-putting, you have no option, that I found, of zooming into your menu as any click you attempt to make on it just exits it, you also have no way of clicking on certain chat options meaning that you will have to figure out the commands to get into specific chats.  The graphics have clearly been inspired from Cube World and I swear that the long grass looks like it has been directly ripped from that game and it feels like they have taken too much inspiration from Cube World for it not to be a blatant rip off. I haven't played it for long and that will be a factor into my rash hatred of the game, however first impressions are always important and this game failed to impress.

The Bad: -I never got into the game. The 25+ minutes I have spent on this game were waiting in login queues. -You have to download the developer's own software platform and make an account for that -You then have to set up a username on their website for Trove.  I've heard this game is good, but the fact that is was '1000+' on the waiting list to play an  MMO  is absurd. They should have expected this turnout. It's a free-to-play voxel-based build-a-thon on  Steam.  They should have had the server capacity to handle this from  day one. The fact that the devs were this incompetent make me not want to even try to play this game ever again.
