Do not let my hours on game fool you, as I do not play through Steam. I've been playing since Open Beta release. The game looked VERY promising, and I was instantly addicted to the feel and abilities of my players. When I first started, there were 4 classes available: Knight, Gunner, Fae Trickster, and Neon Ninja. I was fortunate enough to unlock all the new classes they have released since then, especially now that - while possible to get the classes without paying, you'll be waiting a long time for a server patch big enough to reward you with a 'class coin' to unlock a class. I currently have 4 saved from different times.  Once this game went out of Beta and released on Steam, there have been major improvements server-side. There were queues to get into the game for 60+ minutes at times, and now they're rebuilding the infrastructure to include better gameplay/graphic abilities.  Overall, if you're a collector this game is for you. Unfortunately(much to my despise) they instituted a PvP Arena(which is fairly balanced by all measures) that awards items that a collector such as myself are forced to endure a part of play that I do not enjoy in order to attain these items.  The game is very fast-paced once you go into the adventure realms. You go from dungeon to dungeon killing bosses for chests that contain loot, and more and more rare items to be found. The amount of collecting in this game took me 8 months just to finish all the different weapon styles available(and made by players).  The movable house (Cornerstone) is a good idea, and now you can have multiples. In the harder Adventure worlds the cornerstones are less and less available, making healing/loot collecting a might bit harder.  However: I am noting that this is more Trionworld's fault than it is the Developers, but the game has become increasingly P2P. The bonuses players receive by purchasing a subscription are sickening to me. What took me 6 months to do, they can do in 2 now.  The marketplace is already inflated, and is going to get even more so. There is only 1 in-game-currency sink in the game, and it only inflates prices even further than before.  People are allowed to play on multiple instances in the game to exploit collecting different types of items so long as they're not automated... but come on- we all know it happens. The community can be a bit trying at times. There are many rude people, a lot of younger people, and some salty people. Overall most just like to have fun and spammers are quickly dealt with. Trading is pretty much flawless. You can't get ripped off unless you allow yourself to be. Fishing is arduous, but the collection is pretty nifty. You can get different trophies for different size fish, as well as trophies for every mob in the game (some are unavailable now and fetch a steep price).  8.5 / 10 I still play, I will continue to play until I am forced to pay out of pocket to enjoy my experience.

Nearly 3 hours in. I still haven't played a single second of the game.  Update: tl;dr: Enjoying the game, but when I first started playing I had major technical issues.  It seems as of the day after I posted this the servers have improved massively, I just didn't get around to updating the review.  Although I can't speak for everyone, my personal experience for the first 4 hours or so of dealing with trove was very poor. The signup for 'glyph' would repeatedly refuse my passwords, and would take quite a long time to send the emails. After near-on an hour messing around with the signing up I managed to get in game, only to be greeted with huge wait times to even connect.  This only proceeded to annoy me further as you can't change settings (fullscreen, sound options, resolution, ect) until you have SUCCESSFULLY JOINED the game.  I personally was annoyed by this to no ends because despite the horrendous state of the servers (when I originally posted), yet they had a working micro-transaction store.  After getting in-game I was repeated encountering my computer completely crashing (which happened on no other games), but this seems to have stopped now. (This was likely a problem on my side, but as I said, it happened only on Trove).  BUT.  After all this, I managed to finally be able to play the game, and I am actually really enjoying it. I still don't like the fact it has the availability of micro-transactions but I have yet to feel like they actually influence the game, since the game contains no PvP (that I can see), and I am really not feeling any pay-walls or 'pay2win' at all.  I usually don't defend the mindless comments like 'itz nut pay2wen itz pay 3 shurtcut' but I can safely say that it does feel like one of those rare occasions when the only people paying will be those who have too much money to play the game properly.  There are a lot of bugs still in-game, and the servers still like to die a lot randomly though, but they seem to be being resolved over time.  Also loot in dungeons drops per person, so there will be no loot stealing or similar, and that I really like.  Overall the gameplay itsself is really solid, but only if you can see through the major flaws it has covering it.

First of all, I play Minecraft, and although people think Trove is a ripoff of that, I think it's not. Second of all, I haven't played that much, but still like it (a lot)! Minecraft's about building and exploring, but this actually is more, combat-y.  Pros: + You wanna get stuff, it might be biome-based. Means it's more exploration-based + Unique building (unlike Minecraft, in this you can also get rarer drops from mining) + LOTS of cosmetics + LOTS of hats (TF2 anyone?) + LOTS of weapons + LOTS of customization in general. + Wide, open-world + Difficulty of worlds are balanced, so you don't need to farm that much to survive the next world. + Free + Only paid things are cosmetic, although you have to pay for boosters (premium rank) + Devs notify you when servers will go down (if they are) + Bugs are addressed and action taken quickly + Mounts + Wings (Awesome Face Ball anyone?) + Variety of enemies and bosses, from giant furnace things to pirate parrots. + A lot of other things + No compulsory PVP  Cons: - Premium Rank costs a lot, which heavily unbalances the game - The default keys are annoying (Q is right above 1, which I use a lot, which can be /very/ annoying) - Long wait times (not always though, and it's an MMO so it's not entirely a con, just an annoyance) - Limited skills  Total: 9.8/10 'Not enough classes' - IGN (JK, there's quite a few)

Pretty simple concept: find a dungeion, kill the boss, grab the loot. Repeat.  So why is it so addicting?  I dont normally like this kind of repetition, but I can not stop.   Neat features:  You can go mining. With a laser.  You can build a house that 'goes with you'. What I mean by that is there are specific places you can put your house called 'cornerstones'. They are pads with a sign in front of them. Activate the sign and your house pops up there. YOur house is completely customizable as long as it remains within the confines of the cornerstone. (conrnerstones are all one size)  The weapon and gear system is unique here. Once you collect a style, you can apply it to anything you equip.   Well, thats all I can think of right now., The only reason I had the time to write this review is because the servers are down for a patch =(

Oh boy. Hold down left mouse and press the 1 or 2 button a few times, use some basic exploits to trap the boss in a hole while you poke at him unharmed for 10 minutes until he finally dies. Experience running around and killing stuff over and over again while farming for stuff that requires like 5000 items to make something that looks kind of cool but doesn't actually improve your abilities or gameplay, just to realize that there's this one set and a few hundred others like it that you can BUY for like 10 bucks.  Emerse yourself in getting slightly better stuff every 50 dungeons that feels absolutely no different nor does much different. Meet shallow classes with different versions of decent looking attacks that all do the same thing then hop into an exploitable dungeon where you just hop around for a while and hit stuff while demanding absolutley no skill whatsoever because there are no dodge mechanics and the game just assumes you have enough DPS to kill him before he kills you. Oh, and did I mention that there are only so many dungeons, they're all really short and boring, can be simply skipped and jumped over depending on how many jumps you can use or how many bombs you have, only to make it to a boss with no redeeming qualities?  Why does anyone continue to play this game? There is absolutely no challange other than mindlessly hacking and slashing away at useless crapand the possiblility that you don't have enough DPS for the boss.  Uninspired, lame old blocky graphics, boring/redundant gameplay, pointless farming, undifferentiated weapons, NO PvP, characters that supremely outDPS others, oh yeah, and a FISHING ACTIVITY WHERE YOU F***ING STARE AT THE SCREEN FOR AN HOUR WAITING FOR YOUR BAIT TO BOB SO THAT YOU CAN GET A BORING FISH THAT YOU CEN SELL FOR MINISCULE AMOUNTS OF MONEY. AND THEN DO IT AGAIN. AND AGAIN. AND AGAIN. WHAT?  Who thought that this was a good idea? 3/10 for decent community and slight appeal at first, but I can't believe I was actually sucked in by the promisse of 'better loot!' thus wasting 50 hours of my life.  Do not download this game.

I am going to write the cons of this game first, as they have nearly made me want to stop playing the game.  Cons:  1) The servers are consistantly crashing.  2) The dungeons in the game are to ridiculous for one man to accomplish. To many NPC's in one rooms and it's nearly impossible to avoid dying. How I see this can be fixed is by dungeon que's or something to force players to team up to defeat dungeons.  3) NO PVP, big let down for me.  4) Pay to win majorly, if you actually purchased one of the packages, you are pretty much OP if you get legendary items, or buy wings. You pay for stats in the game which I don't really agree with.  5) It's similar to Minecraft, just this is free. They have a few neat improvements that Minecraft should've done from the start, but this game is nearly the same feel to it at this point in time.  Now time for the Pros of the game.  Pros:  1) The game has absolute potential to be the most played game of 2016, just they really need to take this money they are recieving and put it into a better DNS or VPN. Consistant crashes and reconnects is a fast way to loose your players.  2) So many players online! This is great for if you want to meet friends and etc, though the crashes are from how many players they have gotten since the release.  3) Colorful and imaginative.  4) Mounts, wings, and more! I like how this game is not directed towards a set time frame, such as Medieval. The way the game runs is pretty outstanding with wierd designs that are supported in by the community.  5) The game relies on one to run with a group of players in order to succeed. Though the way you do this is not quite user friendly. I am a level 7 and still have not yet been able to figure out how to make a Clan/Group/Guild. Many players call it different things in game.  My reccomendations to the player(s).  Make sure you have a good internet connection, and plenty of storage for the game. The game at this time takes a lot of data to run, so make sure you have some RAM on deck. From what I have heard and seen, the developers are trying to make it to where ANY PC user can play it, regardless of how low or high priced it is. Make sure you do talk to people and try to form groups to complete challenging dungeons together, otherwise you will loose your magic power when you die, which is what allows you to hit high rates on the NPC. Be sure to also tell your friends to join for perks and what not through the offical webpage. RAF is a great bonus for the game with neat prizes for your efforts.  I still think the game needs immediate action taken on the servers. This game will only go downhill with a high name on Steam at Rank 10. Developers, you need to get to work now before this amazing game just dissapears.

I'm not going to compare this game to Cube World, this game is a thing of its own.  The main reason why this game has 2500 bad ratings, is because of the queues. Which shouldn't be a proper excuse, some people are getting 1000m+ wait time... That's not normal. And I mean that's not normal, the usual wait time is literally 5-30 minutes if the servers are crowded. The developers are doing all they can, and people are also complaining of lag spikes. It's because so many people are trying to access the servers... How about you come back when the servers are upgraded and write a proper review after 10+ hours of gametime? That'd be great!  Edit: Also It's f*cking free to play. Why does it matter?  Personally, I rate this game a solid 8.5/10.  The grinding for mastery levels can get difficult but you know. There are other ways to level up mastery, a good way for me is to find lots of Relics (U-2 World) and use the Loot Collector. Eye of Q'buthulu(?)'s everywhere! The reason why I couldn't give it a 9 is because there's no party system like in WoW yet, me and my friend would love a party system so we could see each others HP and Energy bar.   Another issue I kind of have is that the HUD Is a bit sketchy when it comes to being hurt. There's no signal your health is lowering either fast or slow, your screen doesn't change colour until you're in the last 5%. This hasn't got me killed yet, but I feel it will soon. I just wish there was a better damage indicator. This will sound weird, but one like the Super Street Fighter IV Would be amazing; always knowing when you're around half-health. It's useful, you know?  Now, this game has microtransactions. But funny enough, you don't need to buy anything to advance in the worlds! Sure it'd speed it up by a bit, but in the end it will feel better if you grind for Pearl's of Wisdom instead of getting 3 with the Power Pack. For $20/£15. And they aren't huge leaps anyway, you'll be able to buy a good mount with the in-game currency that I can't remember the name of. You know, the hollowed out rectangle that's multicoloured. that one.  I just recommend everyone to give this game a shot once the servers are either a bit more dead or they're upgraded. It will give a much better experience, as I've seen no valid reasons why not to like this game... bye

I have 50 hours in this game. I feel that it will soon transform to 100 and hundreds more after that.  The thing about this game that makes it annoying is there is so much encouragement to keep playing, keep grinding, keep fighting, keep upgrading, keep crafting, keep collecting, keep exploring, etc.  With the new expansion coming out, 'Mantle of Power' that will essentially double the amount of time it takes to max out a class makes the game more compelling and exciting, with more biomes, abilities, item rarity, mounts, levels, and classes, right now is a great time to pick up Trove.  First of all, there is so much this game hands to you for free. You start the game with one class you may choose. This is not a game that restricts any classes in the beginning. You can play any class you want. However, getting new classes costs Credits, the game's premium currency, but this is not a problem.  With the game's feature of a player market, many items that may seem 'Pay To Win' or 'Premium' can be bought and traded for via community, such as Class Coins and Cosmetics. It simply is not right to call this game pay to win. A better way to say it is pay to advance. The game has a very fun sense of progression, and limitless amounts of items to farm and grind for. If that's not your type of thing, simply buy advancement.  There are many biomes and types of dungeons to grind with your friends it seems like my life is starting to slip into the abyss. All I know is Trove.   Combat is not too intuitive, but still fun nevertheless. Professions really make the game grindworthy, such as ringcrafting, runecrafting, gardening, and crafting. Another fun feature of the game is Mastery Rank, which measures how much experience you have in the game. Your mastery rank stays the same as you switch between classes.  Overall I think it would take you over 70+ hours to max out a class in the game. There are 14, and with the new expansion coming out that expands class level limit, It's going to be one hell of a grind.   So, in conclusion - Trove is a well polished voxel sandbox MMORPG definitely worth downloading and playing. Very grindy and time consuming, and contains the ability to switch in between classes without having to make a new account, reducing repetetive gameplay and enhancing the game experience.  I feel this game is within the 9/10 & 9.5/10 range of a game, but because of how much time this game is sucking out of me I'm giving it a..   10/10 - Download and see for yourself if you like it. This review cannot contain all the positives of the game, and while there are cons, they really don't effect the game in ways that would dull down your enjoyment.

I decided to rewrite this and turn it into an actual review.  Trove is interesting to say the least, with intricate yet simple crafting, bright colors, diversity of classes, and a huge amount of customization - I mean, where do you start with a game like this?  Well we'll start with the pretty colors since that'll take the least time to go over. One of the main reasons I was drawn to Trove in the first place was because of its beautiful color palette and cubic/pixelized art style - in short, it looked like a ton of fun. What's great about this is that while colorful, it's very rare that my eyes get tired of seeing the wide array of shapes and color.  Next is customization, there's plenty to do here with mounts, wings, boats, sails, mag(netic) riders, allies, equipment, and so on - quite frankly, there's so much customization here it's kind of scary (in a good way). It's highly unlikely you'll find many people running around with the same exact stuff as you, which shows how much thought Trion put into customization of characters (as well as loot drops).  After that, crafting - now I'm not going to stay here long because after reading about all of the customization, you can see where crafting is heading - in fact, I think I'll just leave crafting for you to imagine for yourself.  Lastly, a topic that seems to have sparked heated remarks in the comments sections of reviews all across Trove's page - diversity of classes. Now when beginning Trove, players can choose any class they wish for free - after that, they can get a few more for free as they progress through the game (now comes the contraversy), you can also choose to spend money on classes *Gasp*. Now, the reason many have been uptight about this is because while (as far as I know) it is entirely possible to gain every character class for free, it requires a LOT of grinding. *Double Gasp* Grinding?! In a game about loot and customization?! Who does that? Game devs, WHY U DO THIS??!  Because if they didn't you'd get bored with the game way too easy and they would have to pump out WAY more content every day than they did the day before, just to keep players satisfied, which is selfish of the player, completely unreasonable, and unattainable. It simply isn't possible for game devs to keep going at that pace forever - especially if they aren't making any money off of it. They have bills to pay just like you and me folks, which brings us to (Dramatic Music Here) paying for stuff in-game.  You can grind for a while and earn almost everything in-game, or you can just accelerate the process by paying real money to get the classes you want (This is MUCH quicker).  Quite frankly, if you can't stomach the fact that game devs running a Free-to-Play have given players the option to buy certain things to make their gameplay experience go a bit more streamlined, then you have no business playing video games period.  Again, they've got bills to pay too, and to ask them to provide these services without the option to pay for some of their services - is to ask them to be slaves, and that's not cool guys.  Don't be slave drivers, just have fun.

Fun MMORPG feel, A lot of freedom, and movement is great. Art style is neat. Gameplay could use some improvements and such. But one thing that needs to be fixed. Servers. +The game is free. +Cute graphics +Lots of things to collect +You can build your own little world +I really like how many things you can collect (equipment skins, pets, mounts, fishes, boats, sails, fishing rods, etc.)  -Super repetative You kill stuff by clicking your mouse, and you sometimes use your 3 abilities and a healing potion. -The game is simple. Too simple. Lots of players still have problems with the simplest things though, like finding dungeons (which is the gaming equivalent of tying your own shoelaces), so I suppose the target audience of this game is basically... kids and special people. -The equipment system is ♥♥♥♥♥♥. Super, SUPER BAD. There isn't enough randomness and stat variety in it. This means that you'll rarely EVER find upgrades to your gear. Seriously. There aren't many equipment slots either. Finding loot isn't fun that way. It is rather boring, actually. As a fresh character you'll find Uncommon items. Play a few minutes and you'll only find rare items. A few more minutes with your char and you'll only find epics. A few more minutes and you'll only find legendaries. A bit later on relics and higher quality items become completely commonplace as well. once I dinged lvl10 (takes only a few hours), I didn't find an item upgrade for about 20 hours of gameplay when I was already lvl22. This is bad design. -The gameplay is rather antisocial -The playerbase is rather antisocial -The online gaming's usual 'European servers = Russian speaking servers' -LONG queues. You go afk for a short few minutes to get a drink and BAMM. Kicked for idling, welcome to the 220 minutes long queue. -Frequent crashes -Bugs. Some of them are quite annoying, like how you have to bind your keboard every time you connect to the game. (This happens a LOT due to client and server crashes)

So just imagine, Minecraft took it's grass block, stuck it in the o of WoW and it didn't fit. But Minecraft made it fit. And over the course of 9 months, Trove was made.
Do you have time and friends? Play this. Do you have money? Play this. Do you play for fun? Play this.  Do you really, really dislike grinding? Don't play this(although the grind isn't that bad).

Soo after taking a break from the game I came back and there are a lot of changes.  The gem system You now can have gems equiped on your classes, these boost your stats and give you more PR. We have 3 types of gems, Water, Air and Fire. You can equip 3 gems on each type (2 tiny gems and 1 empowered gem).  You are no longer able to buy classes with cubits Now I disagree with this feature, but the good part is that you can still buy classes with flux soo in the end you can still get the class you want by playing the game.  Battle Arena When I played we didn´t have a pvp mode, now we do. You have two battle modes Catch the Flag and Team Death Match.  Is The Game P2W? The definition of P2W changes from person to person. Pay to Win for me is when you can directly buy better gear or allow you to make better items then everyone else making the game unbalanced.  Now I think Trove is Pay to Progress Faster kind of game, Player X can buy wings from the store with real money while Player Z will take 3 days to get the flux to buy those wings in-game.  Soo after all these changes do I still recomend the game? Yes. It is definetly harder for new players to get into the game and progress, but if you enjoy the game you won´t have problems. In the end is up to the person playing to define if the game is for you or not.  -------------------------------------------------------//------------------------------------------//--------------------------------------  I normally don't review for games but I had to give my opinion on this one. I started playing in November, one of my friends from another game recomended it to me, my first thought of the game while watching youtube videos about it was: ' Another minecraft clone? Hmm oh well im gonna try it anyways'....Now I look back and think how wrong I was. Currently I am a veteran player I have spent hours in this game and I totally love it.  Classes -You can choose between 11 classes and switch to another class whenever you want, wanna play a Ninja that can hide in the shadows and trow shurikens? Wanna play has an undead mage that call skeletons from the dead? Or maybe has a pirate that travels the sea? You can choose anything you want. -All of them are unique with different weapons and play style you will have fun leveling each one of them up.  Environment -Trove not only gives us a variety of classes to choose from but it gives us a lot of biomes to discover. -From a sky realm, undead biome, treasure isles, and much more you will have your hands full with exitment.  Mounts, Boats, Wings and....Dragons!? -Ever thought about mounting a spider, a frozen cat or even an war horse? Well fear not trove has all that and much more. -You can travel the sea with many diferent boats and sails, and guess what?! They even come with canons that can tear your enemies to dust. -Who doesnt want to discover the wonders of a realm in the sky? well with trove wings you can do just that and..well look cool while doing it. -The newest addicion on trove regasrding mounts were Dragon...now who doesnt want a dragon has a mount? But trion didnt let it just end like that, they made it soo dragons cold fly and even shoot fireballs!!  Professions -Trove gives us players a variety of professions to level up each of them beying unique and diferent. -Runecrafting, Ringcrafting, Gardening and Fishing.  The Developer Team -I think this is something i need to talk about, the developer team here on trove is totally different from soo many others. -They are always watching us, they interact with us in game, they LISTEN (in this case read) our concerns about the game and even take our suggestions.  PVP -Many people were disapointed pvp was not in the game but fear not its coming, the developers are working on it.  Cornerstones -This is an unique feature trove has, you have your own little pocket house were you can destroy, construct and do anything you like with it.  Clubs -Trove doesnt have Guilds it has Clubs, you can join up to 5 clubs at a time. -Constuct and interact with your friens in clubs.  Cons -Trove is not only positive things it has is problems too here are some of them:  -End game content laking.  -It can get repetitive and a little bit grindy somethimes.  Conclusion Stop Reading And Go Play It! 9/10

One of the best MMO-type Minecraft-esque game I've played in a very long time. This is by far one of the best PLAY-to-win games on the FREE market. Nearly everything you can buy with real cash you can get by playing the game regularly (with the exception of skins for classes). The grind isn't as HORRIBLE as Warframe. I'll list some pro's and con's from the few hours I've played:  Pros: - Classes have very few skills (4 in total) but those skills complement each other EXTREMELY well. When you play one, you know that the skills that they have were to be used in a certain way. - As stated above, everything is buyable by simply PLAYING THE GAME.  - For the first 10 levels, it's not too hard. You can get by with each character playing it safe. Past that, difficulty skyrockets and the game forces you to do extremely difficult end-game dungeons with multiple players so it doesn't turn into Solo-Fighter-Online - The 'base' system was extremely well thought out. You build your home and everytime you need something from home, you bring the home to YOU rather than being teleported to another place.   Cons: - EXTREMELY laggy at some points in the game. Usually after 2 PM EST, the servers will fill up to maximum capacity at which point you will be put on a queue. This queue on average lasts 20 minutes and will fluctuate up and down depending on how many people are on the queue with you. - Frequent downtimes on the servers for maintenance or hotfixes that last a long, long time. It only feels that way because the game is so good.   Keep in mind this only got released recently and the team has been working their ASSES off trying to get servers back online in working order to service this buttload of players. All in all, this is an extremely satisfying game to play if you have any interest in MMO's or Crafting/Minecraft-esque games.

Trove is an amazing mmorpg game, to be honest it is probably one of my favourite mmorpg.   Pros:   - Amazing community, lots of people playing and the people are helpful to new players  - The graphics are very simple yet very nice to look at.  - The gameplay is fun you can use any of the wide variety of classes to play as.   - Leveling up and/or proceeding through the game does not require mini transactions. Mini transactions only change the visual aspect of your characters.  - The trading system is great.   Cons:  - You will need patience and some time to level up and proceed to higher mastery ranks to unlock new things. But that is not a big problem since you would probably play this game a lot, if you like mmorpgs.

---Update 8/15/15:--- I don't really know what happened. I guess the novelty just wore off over time, and I find myself thoroughly disinclined to play this game anymore. I'm mostly disappointed that I kept my faith in the developers for as long as I did.   This game falls short when it comes to it's mid-endgame 'challenges,' which are hourly events that reward players with an rng chest that mostly just spits out a bunch of flux, which is considered the main currency and is the primary material you use to upgrade your weapons. Challenges are not fun. Every hour on the hour you have twenty minutes to clear dungeons in a specified biome, with bonuses for playing as one of two specified classes, and a bonus for playing on one of the two highest 'difficulty' worlds.  People complain that this leads to zerging, which I only did once before deciding that I just wouldn't do it. Because it's not fun. I thought that I would instead spend my time mining for other materials and save up to be able to trade when a global market comes out. A few weeks later and I'm still waiting for that promised update.  And this is where my disappointment really kicks in. Devs put out a lot of new content every week. This would be great, but each round of new content comes with new and more bugs and issues. If you're like me and don't encounter these issues yourself, you get to experience the disappointment of seeing them brought up in the forums and realize that there's even more work to be done before they can even get to focusing on content updates that you actually care about, the ones that actually mean anything.  There's promises of upcoming changes to challenges, and promises of a global market being introduced, but I fear that by the time these things come out, there will be so many bugs and issues with every update between now and then that it'll take even more weeks before these updates will have their own bugs ironed out. And by that time there will be even more content with even more bugs to further perpetuate the issues.  It's a fun game, and it seemed like it was going in the right direction, but I fear that unless the devs pull back on adding new content and spend a few update cycles dedicated to bug fixes, this game will progressively get more and more difficult to enjoy, as it already has been.  My optimism for this game and it's developers has turned into disappointment, but as a free game, it may still be worth trying. Personally, I do plan to continue to keep an eye on the game's forum and log in once in a while, however, I can no longer say that I particularly recommend this game.   ---Update 7/30/15:---  Due to the issues of a patch release causing downtime that lasted most of the day, players who log in this weekend should obtain free items. I'm not sure if completely brand new players will be able to get in on the free class token and cubits, but it might be a good time to join just in case.  Queues and wait times have been reduced considerably, but there's still some waiting once in a while. Last week there was a lot of lag issues to contend with as well, though I believe most of that should be fixed with the current state of the game. There was mention of a bug involving enemies walking out of the loaded area of a world causing the database to start to cave in on itself. These two days since the aformentioned patch downtime have been pretty smooth for playing, but I did have a five minute queue to wait one of the times I logged in yesterday.   The game is still definitely fun. Since my first review, I've leveled up one of my characters to 20 and have reached 30 mastery, getting me in on challenges. Essentially challenges are timed dungoen rush missions that grant bonus rewards for completing enough quests in the specified time.   There are also plans to add another class soon along with inventory expansions (though the inventory expansions may be restricted to being purchased with currency that can only be obtained through spending real money). This may be a bit of an issue, but one way around this is to utilize club worlds (you can be a member (or owner) of up to 5) and the storage space granted by creating and using specail 'club chests' there.   If you were turned away by the queues before, I'd say give it a try now. They're still around, but not nearly to the extent of half-hour wait times as they were before. Devs are continuing to strive for a game that's fun for everyone, including free players, thankfully not caving in to unreasonable demands made by 'the ones that paid.'   There's still plenty of kinks, but the game continues to be thoroughly enjoyable.   ---Original 7/19/15 Review---  This is an amazing game and the Devs are working like mad to sort out the limited server space issues that cause long queues. Please be patient or at least come back in a few weeks as things get improved and fixed. In the meantime, they have been giving some free items to players who have had to deal with downtimes, to thank them for continuing to play the game in spite of downtimes.  The game is incredibly fun and well worth the wait, especially once you're able to turn off the in-game music so that waiting in the queue doesn't affect doing something else like watching stuff on youtube or listening to your own music. The music in the game is okay, but partially as a result of the queue, not worth listening to compared to having your own music playing. Personally I've found the OST from the Mother series to be quite fitting anyway.   I ramble, but the point is this is a great game that's just off to a rocky start. I really hope for it to succeed and encourage anyone interested to either put up with the queues and server downtime or just be sure to check back once things do smooth over.

Okay, seriously, I like this game, a lot, beginning my second time playing it. There are a lot of classes, and I picked neon ninja, got my class coin, and got gunslinger. After this, I was bored, and stopped playing it. Alright, let's step back... Everything but the classes is pretty good in this game. Now, even the good parts of the classes makes it/them bad. The problem is, most of the classes are downright awesome. Why's this a problem? Because I end up not knowing which one to pick, and then pick two with a class coin, and get bored by trying to level the two equally. I've played about ninety hours of this at the point of making this. Oh, by the way, this game is practically p2w, except, you can play without that. This game isn't like others, 100% pvp, this is mostly pve, making pay to win not really all there. It's not winning, it's just taking your time, and progressing. Game's pretty good, after me taking a second look at it... But, again, classes. I've had to make how many accounts? I have made, drumroll... Five accounts. To make an account, you have to go through the process of making another email. So, thanks. That's made it a lot more annoying, and I end up switching between accounts because I don't even really know what class I want to play. Which is just me, making this game even better. Yes, you have to waste A LOT of time on this, but, once you get all your work and such done for the day, it's your time. You can waste as much time as you want on this. Anyway, probably... 8/10, in my current mood. Recommended... Hard.

Not for the weary nor anyone that doesn't want to grind,everything. Not a game you can rush - even if you want to. Sure you could get power leveled to 30, but then getting suitable gear is another grind in itself, and you miss out on gaining easy power score increase by skipping to the end.  Gameplay has remained steady for years - the only things that changed were new items added, making more to grind for. At first it was to level 20, now its 30, and special end game items.  You will need to play frequently to 'keep up' or fall into the loop of being behind, or worse, the 'Pay to catch up' aspect.  Trion is all about paid options, and Trove is no exception. Services that were free/limited are now strictly pay. It's not 'P2W' however as someone can pay $0 and still be 'End Game, Top Tier' - they just have to focus harder to do it.  I Recommend this game ONLY to those willing to put serious time into pointless grind. The 'bosses' are a joke, there is still no quest/story line after over 2 years, and all drops are completely random. Getting 'better gear' simply means grinding more, be it to craft them, or to find them and enhance them.  You will quickly fall behind on the 'current dragon unlock' unless you play everyday, even then you may not fully unlock the dragon before the next event starts - but at least you won't be paying nearly double resources after the event to fully unlock. (always focus on events going on - be they holiday specials or weekly, the items remain available afterwards except for event specific items)

At the start of this review i would like to point out that i hate or voxel/minecraft-ish games. This one is the only difference to back up the rule. Pros: -really easy to learn -awesome community that tries to help anyway it can -addictive mmo experience -crafting plays a big role in game -great optimization, plays well even on low-end pcs Cons:  -Repetitive dungeons -Quest (or whatever you want to call it) description sometimes lacks information (do this with that but doesnt say where you can get that) - weird mouse movement sometimes when it turns 180 deegres even if your mouse stays where it was Trion has 2 big mmos in their arsenal of games: Trove and Archeage. If you are looking for some chill time smashing blocks Trove is for you. If you prefer something more realistic (as far as fantasy goes) i would recommend archeage for overall better combat and depth of game. My final score of the game is 7+/10 and i would highly recommend it to people that want to give voxels a try (just like i did).

start game - 40min waiting queue. got in after an hour. pressed 'alt' on the keyboard and got locked ( probably bug ) in a free mousecurser mode, unable to end it again which actualy makes the game unplayable. so I was forced to restart the game to fix this. restart game - 360min waiting que, 20min later - 399min queue. (In the end it only took 90min)  after 6h of playing and 4h of sitting in the queue: + game is can be fun in short bursts, if you like grinding and minecraft mining. + no pay2win + good tutorial like quests  - - Intense lags, almost always. - - server crashes / disconnects - no options while waiting in queue. unable to stop the loud and annoying music the game plays. - every class is limited to 3 skills, no talent trees to customize - if you chose a class you don't like, you have to play it anyway to get the ressources to buy a new one. only the first class you choose is free. - the Trove community sucks balls (at least EU). noone will talk to you or invite you in a club (guild/clan)  If you have a lot of time to sit in waiting queues and enjoy minecraft collecting and casual combat give it a try. it's only 750mb in size and you won't ever feel the need to pay anything for this game.  But the login waiting time alone is enough to not recommend this game.

While it's fun and all, there are some negative aspects people just so happen to leave out.  It's a real grind fest. You can't even comprehend. I was gathering materials, day after day just to build something to allow me entry into a new area. I never did manage to get enough.  Daily limited currency. Although the new tutorial quests made it a little easier to start off with cubits, you're still limited to 500 a day (1000 on weekends), where most items in the store cost anywhere from 5000 to 20,000 cubits (such as classes and potions).  Frame rate drops. I don't know how many others are affected, but it happens to me very often still. At times the game will slow down to a crawl or experience micro freezes, what makes it really annoying is how the camera will spin wildly into random directions.  As alredy mentioned by others, it's very repetitive. You enter a zone, find the nearest dungeon, kill one of the 3 or so possible bosses (they all look different, but there's only so many different AI types in the game), grab your 2 items reward and move on to the next dungeon. There's visual variety, but all those different dungeons are user submitted, some of which are really horrible to navigate.  If you're easily annoyed by such things, then skip it until it gets some improvements.

This game, well. Unfortunately I've been unable to play for a while because of work and other commitments. But I felt that this game deserves a review.  The game at a first look seems like it is designed for little kids to run around and whilst that is very true it also makes plenty of room for the more hardcore gamers.  You start the game with a class that you choose which is randomly generated. You can then choose your look at your pre built safe house which you can openly customise whenever the hell you want! By that I mean no one players house looks at all the same! (unless you've got two players that have just started) Like, you can edit and change every individual block and there's no limits either, resources are super easy to obtain and special blocks are a little harder but to build your basic safehouse you have a whole world of mineable blocks around you! and it doesn't end there. You can build where ever you are. It doesn't have to be in your designated safe house area. (of course it won't stay there, but you can build outside of the home area if you want. this is just another example of the kind of freedom you get in the game)   The combat is indeed repetative, but strangely satisfying! Like, you just don't get tired of it. Choose your class wisely as this is going to be your class for a while but shortly after playing into the game a bit you will be able to unlock anothe class until you eventually unlock all the classes. (don't get me wrong, at the start you can choose any class to start with) when you unlock all the classes you can seemlessly switch between any of the classes on a single account. I'm talking, you can be halfway through a dungeon and be like 'I'm bored of this class now' press the shortcut key and switch to another unlocked class on the fly!    The crafting on the game seems bottomless with tonnes of new amazing things you want to craft in the game giving you tonnes of new things to do, dungeons are easy to find and range from easy to difficult to clear and then you have shadow arena's which are even harder and require a team. Each have better or worse drops depending on difficulty, magic find and how lucky you are and everything contributes in one way or another to crafting.   and then there's the customisation! just to start, this game is very moddable. You can find all sorts of visual mods on the web, from HUD mods and armor mods and even the colour and effects of the visuals. But if you don't fancy messing around with the modding side of things you have unlimited options inside the game. You find some really amazing weapon with the best stats ever after completing a really hard shadow dungeon with your Neon Ninja. The only problem is that this badass weapon is a giant lollipop... Whilst some might like that idea, some might want a badass ninja with a flaming radient sword! By simply pressing C you can literally change the skin of your sword to any of the other weapons you've broken down previously in the game. I'm talking every sword you ever picked up from anywhere. If it has rubbish stats you still want to pick it up if it looks good. Chances are, you might not have the skin for it yet. So you can break it down to get the skin and of course some valuable flux (which helps you craft and serves as currency in the game)     Of course, it's not all rainbows and butterflies. On some days you can get unbareable lag (which gets better and better every day with constant communication from the devs I might add)   The trade system is something you will get into eventually in the game. This game is still in early days yet. But trade is literally tapping into trade chat and selling things the old mmorpg way (WTB 2 pentaforge) bla bla. And then to trade you have to teleport to the player you want to trade with (it's easy to do when you get the hang of it) and use a nearby trading post which is a tad buggy at times. I get the feeling and kind of hope that this is just a quickfix solution for trading until they decide to implement something more concrete into the game.    I can't really think of too many negative things about the game but what I can say is that the Positives most definitely outweigh the negatives!    Definitely worth a try, it's free so what you got to lose?

Its all a bunch of spammers and noobs asking for help getting something.    What it needs implmented: Auction houses(somewhere for trade so it doesnt clog chat). Better turtorial, Its alright. but when it says go from getting a sky realm to forging something to getting level 30 mastery its kindof redic. OR when it says get a club, What if i dont want a club? Stuff like that shouldn't be there, its forcing people to ask in chat 100 times.    So, overall I recommend this game. but if your into less-grind games then don't. I understand alot of rpgs are grind, but its kindof dumb when its like this. And lasty they need to add things to do besides fishing, raiding and grinding.

Funnily enough, i actually really liked trove when i first got it. The problem is in how it is laid out, with there being nothing to do except do endless dungeons (read:grind for 20 hours) to get top- tier equipment. Or you can build up your home, which means you are not progressing whatsoever, so where is the point?   Pros:  Fairly fun if repetitive combat Good if not very inventive character/class design Nice building mechanics. Multi-jump system means you don't have to spend 20 years climbing something.  Cons:  Dungeons are variants of the same thing (there is always a boss, and always one of 2 variants on the boss depending on what zone you are in. Randomised world means there is no visible progression of players. Its takes far to long to get wings, which I think improve the game somewhat (just cos you can, y'know, fly around and make you home into a sort of gliding course) (it take about twice as long as i have played to get anywhere near the rank required for wings) Swapping classes puts you back on square 1 NO inventiveness on either boss or mob design. Classes are either spam 'n' pray or do massive damage.   TL:DR: This is a game that quickly gets old due to its totall lack of inventivesness.

Decent kids MMO with an alright-community building around it. It has good potential to get better with time and support and I certainly recommend it over WOW for younger players. The cartoonish style and the 'we're not minecraft we swear!' crafting element is different enough in gathering items and some building mechanics to work in its favor. Customizing the characters based on what you pick up from enemies is a great touch too.  As of the typing of this review this game gets a solid 7/10 and rising when more updates are made in the future.

They need to add more content, it takes them a while to add content. Particularly the battle portal content for pvp will be fun but they need to imrprove on it and make it less simple. With some updates this game could be really awesome.

Very fun, reminded me of cube world at first, but I find this game to be more fun and very different, with more to do. While there isn't a specific task you are attempting to do, there is still plenty to keep players interested, building in your cornerstone, building in a club world, saving cubits gained from daily quest completion to buy new classes and store mounts/wings/boats, as well as increasing mastery through new allies, mounts, and other equipables. You can find even more to do in Shadow Arenas, dragon challenges, the soon to come shadow towers. You can search for recipe dungeons, forge equipment and level up new classes. Sometimes there are server problems, however that is par for the course, and usually these server problems are fixed quickly. I have had a lot of fun with this game so far and plan to keep doing so for a good ammount of time.

Not really a minecraft clone, instead I would describe this game as an easier, 3d, non-rougelike version of Realm of the Mad God. It has many of the same advantages and good points, with the same set of associated flaws. Not a bad game, but I don't really get much longterm satisfaction from it, it's a quick mindless game, which is enjoyable, but feels somewhat empty after a few hours of repitition. there is persistant progress, and each class is fun to learn and master, but to really get the most out of the game, you need to sink in countless hours of grinding, or contribute to the unfortunate pay-to-win mentality that is so popular in free online games.  So, yeah, overall it's fun, but not particularly deep or inovative.

If you liked classic Minecraft and still do, but wish it had more RPG elements- this is still not game for you. The reason I compare it to (classic) Minecraft is not because of its voxel graphics, but instead because of its popularity, this provides a basis to put my argument upon.  Already on the market there are Minecraft modpacks that are frankly easy to install and have met and well exeeded these standards. This is a game for people to poke around and find what type of playstyle they like. I do not concider it a full fleshed out game, much like the free version of Runescape.  Notes:  A grinding playstyle, with level not really refective to the gameplay. So what are we working towards? Nothing.  I had alot of trouble with the 3rd person perspective and the landscape disign, as well as the building (and destroying) mechanics. It doesn't fit the RPG genre and defintely not in this title.   The Jumping mechanics were-- silly, for lack of a better word. Nobody can jump 14 times in a row in any game and still feel like thats normal, and it DEFINITELY shouldn't be furtherly reinforced in a buyable package.   Cheers.  -Mysterious_Seven

Before you judge my review credibility from my hours played, I have played over 1000 hours of this game easy on Glyth before it was on steam. This game is a very very in-depth game but a causual player can also play this game. If you like grinding, you will like this game. But you don't need to grind to get good items. When you first start you probably will feel very behind and googling things like BEST CHAR IN TROVE???? and FASTEST WAY TO EARN FLUX? and no matter what I say you probably still will. Those guides can help but I think that the best character is just your preference which is why I think this game is so unique from other similar games because there is no dominate character that if you don't have unlocked you will be getting rekt from other more experienced players. This game is perfect for all players for that reason because you can play the game for 1000 hours like me and have all radiant gear or just play the game for a couple of hours and still have fun and get some nice shadow gear for yourself.  I used to play on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ laptop and still get great frames so if your stuck playing on your moms mac, I think you will be fine. The mechanical requirements are very low which introduces the game to more causaul players that don't have access to monster computers.  A lot of the time I find myself grinding but not getting bored because there are a variety of different things that you might grind for. Like every hour there is a opportunity to partcipate in Hourly Dragon Quests which by the way is a great way to not get super bored while grinding on SA's all day.  There are in-game microtransactions but they consist of player skins that do not alter the stats of your character, blocks, and premium currency. The premium currency can be converted into Flux so people could pay to get Flux, but I do not reccomend doing so. Luckly there are no pay-to-win EXP potions or anything so you know that someone with a max character worked for it. Also another way of showing that you didn't pay for your items is Mastery Rank. I am mastery 200 which is max because I have spent a lot of time working for that. But when you come accross a level 20 mastery ranked player with 10 stacks of 9999 Flux you know he ain't legit.  I hope my review helped you realize that you should get into this game and it is not your average free-to-play game where you can just pay and become just as good as a player that has 1000 hours. Have a good day!

I played Trove back in beta, before it was on Steam. It was really fun then, and though it's still fun now, there are some things I wish they had/hadn't changed.  1) In the beta, you could drop items. Now you cannot. This makes trading with other players tedious as you must first travel to a trading post. You can now only store or destroy items. 2) There are too many benches. Crafting is a massive part of this game, but it's very annoying that you must craft a bench to craft a bench to craft a certain item. How about just one bench with a level-tier system for what you can craft? 3) The monetization is stupid. Yes, I know, Trion has to make money somehow, but making some items available only for those willing to pay real money is ridiculous. This is the same nonsense that's plagued F2P games for years. Surely Trion can be more creative than this.  That being said, Trove is still a really fun game. The crafting system is solid and the items are pretty cool. Find a friend to play it with and you can adventure forever. That's actually true, considering the worlds are procedurally-generated. Definitely check this game out.

This game is hella fun once you've figured out how to get out of the Minecraft Mindset.  I felt like I entered the game expecting it to BE minecraft with magic, but it's honestly very different. It's better in many respects, but only because it is centered around a battle/adventure format, and not around a survival/construction format. You don't have to survive or build shelter in this game, you go around destroying and pilaging. That isn't to say you CAN'T build, you can make a club world and expand and create within it, and your cornerstone is whatever structure you would like and it can come with you anywhere!  The one downside I would say is that the gameplay itself can get a little stale, and it becomes a grindy grind collectathon when you're trying to push the limits into the higher end items, and waiting for days at a time to get new classes can be SOOOOOOO BORING, but when you've gotten some headway, and you can transfer better items between classes, it becomes easier to stomach.  I'm going to keep playing this one for a while.

Starting with the negative, this game is grindy, repetetive, and very limited in terms of content. You spend the entirety of the game's leveling process running the same few dungeons over and over and over until you can manage to get to level 20. It takes about 10 hours if you're playing at a normal pace. Then you have to find gear --> grind more dungeons (either for the actual gear or for in-game currency to buy the gear). This takes forever and is frustrating because you just want to play the end-game content. Then, and only then, can you do shadow tower dungeons, which are an underwhelming hack n' slash. Reflecting on the game, it has almost nothing to offer. It won't change your life. There's no storylore, no npcs with backstory, and the pvp is simply horrendous. There are MANY better mmorpgs out there.  That being said, I have logged over 50 hours thusfar and it was a F2P game, so I highly recommend it to waste time :D Thumbs up for sure!

Trove Graphics 6/10 The Graphics in the game aren’t that good. Everything in the game is blocky though it isn’t that bad. The game is made to look like that and if it wasn’t the game couldn’t be so open ended. Changing the look of the game would conflict with a lot of the game.  Story 0/0 There is none  Music 5/10 The music in this game isn’t good isn’t bad. The music doesn’t stand out at all in the game. For example while writing this review i forgot what most of the tracks sound like. They may be not good but I was never bothered by the soundtrack.\  Gameplay 8.5/10 The gameplay in this game is really fun it showcases show cases everything an mmo like it needs. It is quite simple with several different classes you can pick. There is a regular attack, powered attack, special attacks, and ect. There is certain gear you can craft for each of your classes and some gear can apply for multiple classes. Though crafting is not required to get powerful gear. Some boss monsters drop rare gear and there are dungeons that have a chest with two gear pieces if you beat them.  Overall 7/10 with the rating of play it

Trove is a pretty fun game. It can be played completely free and is not pay to win (though paying $ will save you time building your collection). There is some building in the game but nothing to the extent of minecraft. the dungeons are pretty fun and the systems, while simple, feel good.  The one thing you NEED to know about this game is it is all about collection. There are classes that are all wonderfully unique, for you to collect (through play or with $), Class Skins, Mounts (three different kinds, 4 if you count dragons as unique), blocks, craftables, weapons skins, armor skins, fish, allies, etc...  This game is all about collecting everything. Sure it does it with a skin of combat and exploration but if you don't have interest in collecting shiney things Trove will be a fairly short lived diverssion.  That being said I have found collecting to be quite fun and am enjoying Trove immensly. The launch has been a bit rocky with server issues but the beta was super solid and I imagine once they get the kinks worked out the game servers will no longer have issues.  Pick it up and give it a shot, its free after all.

This game......... Is absolutely FANTASTIC.   Pros: - not pay to win - combines RPG, MMO, Sandbox genres all together magically - DO NOT JUDGE THE GRAPHICS BASED ON SCREENSHOTS! this game is gorgeous. Although the art style is Minecraft-esk it still has some of the best lighting effects ive seen. There were times in game when my friend and i would be casually walking to a cave to mine recources when we would suddenly be so gobsmacked by the sunset, we would stand there and stare for a few minutes. Best part is, it is in no way graphically demanding of your PC. - Great class system - Randomly generated dungeons/worlds. What i mean is that the game is split into different areas based on difficulties. if there is no one in a area for 30 minutes it will be randomly re-generated. - club system. Each club gets there own island to do whatever they desire. - Easy to pick up, difficult to master. - Regularly updated - simple yet deep  Cons: - A few bugs, but thats expected in a game that just came out of release. - At times it may feel a bit grindy to get coins, but you really dont need coins. The only thing coins get you are different classes and fishing gear XD. - Severs may need to be optimized - there currently is not Auzzie server, but i expect on to come soon.  All in all, this game is great for free to play. I personally wouldnt mind paying $5 - $10 for it. I recomened this game to people who love MMO's, RPG's and sandbox games. In fact, this game has something for everyone. This game is from the creators of succesfull titles such as rift and Archage, so in my opinions, this game has lived up to that reputation.  8.5/10, 9/10 when bugs are fixed.

Despite my little time played this game has a lot of things to do. Randmly generated world with randomly generated dungeons. It is like that game Cube World but with an MMO twist and not as many blocks to every thing. The game feels like a mix of Cube World and Minecraft. You can ethier build some pixal art or a sweet castle, or grind away in the many many many dungeons of the game. And gameplay is fantastic as well. I am starting to think I am a sucker for AMMORPGs.

I have been playing this game for a while now, and it may be my favourite. You have the option to pay, but you can do everything without paying. Paying just gives you a little bit extra luck and lets you have stuff a bit earlier without waiting to get the money 'Cubits' which doesn't take long to get at all! It is all free, and without paying is no different to paying! You can pay to get wings, but a bit later in the game you'll get some! However, it does take up to 30 minutes some times to get in to the servers, but the wait's worth it, trust me. You can make friends, join clubs (or make one), raid dungeons, fish, ride a boat while shooting your cannon at your enemies, turn in to a dragon, ride a dragon, shoot from your guns and jump really high, fight Shadow Arenas, use swords, summon minions, use flasks to heal from the start of the game you start with 8 flasks, and much more! So start playing now and you'll get addicted and become a master of this game!

This is going to be hopefully a short review.  So I was a little sceptical about the game due to it's Minecraft-like graphics. Read some of the reviews and decided that I will give it a shot, since there were a lot of positive ones. I had nothing to lose, but I was still sceptical after all the positive reviews. So with my first log-in there was like... I can't even describe it. There were a lot of colors, it looked awesome. It looked so simple, you have about 4 spells ( excluding your basic attacks ) which are so simple made. There is no class advance and stuff ( even though you can change your class whenever you like, as long as you charge some real life money) Once I entered combat, the gameplay seemed so smooth, I couldn't believe my eyes. I feel that the live action combat system is very well made, and I might compare it to TERA's combat system, and even say that it feels a little smoother. The community is very, very friendly, so far. Whenever I asked any questions in the Global chat, they always answered me. After some time spent in the game, I found out that the game is not as simple as it seems. There are a lot of instances, and the end-game content seems to be quite good as well. There are a lot of different item grades, for different levels, there are item upgrades. Though there is a different side of the game. The even more minecraft-like. You can farm almost every color material that you see in the world. The world is completely destroyable. There are a lot of dungeons with different type of colored blocks. You can make your dream house, castle, hell you can even create a whole forrest! So far, so good. The only issues I've encountered are the from-time-to-time long server log-ins. Though it says exactly how much time you are supposed to wait, so it's not really a problem for me. The most time I've waited was about 30 min. Usually it is around 10 min, if there is any waiting. Overall the game seems to be very fun.    I hope I helped :)   PS. The Cash Shop is not an issue with the game, people who are using it don't have some kind of strong advantage in the game, so chill your tatas!

I'd like to start off by mentioning that I have spent at the very least 80+ hours while it was in Beta so forgive what appears to be a low play time.  Trove is game that I would highly recommend trying at the very least considering that:  1) It's Free  2) It takes up very little space on your computer (short download time) 3)Seriously, it's free   But aside from that the real selling point of this game from my perspective is that 95% of the content in the game you can obtain through in game currency or earn by playing. The other 5% of the content that you can only purchase using real money is purely cosmetic and doesn't affect gameplay.   Classes? Play about 30 minutes a day (the time it takes to fill your quest bar) for a week and abracadabra you can unlock a new class of your choice.   Mounts? You start with one that is only 20 speed lower than every mount that exhists in the game, every week loot boxes obtained through play have a chance to drop 1 of 2 unique weekly mounts, 2 mounts have a random chance to drop as loot whenever. (There are also several mounts that can be crafted but the aforementioned ways are the easiest/fastest)  Allies/pets? Vendors sell them in boxes (in exchange for an in game earned resource) that randomly give you one of the allies in each set.   Wings? Reach Mastery Rank 20 (Collect styles, learn mounts, fish, level your character etc.)   Gameplay wise you may find it a bit grindy after a while, but hey its a dungeon crawling mmo what were you expecting? A Storyline akin to the elderscrolls games?   Easily one of the best practitioners of the free-to-play model to date

I've been playing Trove since a week into closed beta (So late September 2014). I wasn't too keen in the beginning, the graphics seemed weird to me and it took me a while getting used to the game play in general.  This game has changed so much since then! There's a rather long tutorial line now that shows you the game, the different worlds, so you aren't lost when first starting the game. The combat/adventuring system is really nice with a lot of different classes to choose from. There are a lot of biomes with different monsters and player-created dungeons that change regularly! There's a lot to do in Trove. There isn't a mission or quest line, but you create your own adventure. There are boats, dragons, you can go fishing or fight monsters with various classes. You can customize each class with different styles you can save (there are A LOT of styles), but also different flasks and flask effects (emblems) make your class unique in the way YOU want to play it. Adventuring isn't the only part of the game though. You can build in club worlds with friends or create your own little home in your Cornerstone you can take anywhere with you. There are basically no limiations to your imagination.   Trove is a great game with (so far) weekly updates. Developers working closely with the community on their official forums. I recommend Trove to everyone who loves to make their own fun! :)

I've been playing this game since mid-late Alpha and it's certainly undergone many changes.  If you're looking for a fun adventure game to play with friends, I'd certainly recommend giving it a go.   Quick Pros/Cons:  Pros:  + Combat System + Building + Social Environment + Customizability (Character Styles)  Cons:  - Very grindy after a certain point - Market could use work - In order to build, you'll need to farm or buy many blocks - Gets quite repetitive   Go ahead and give it a shot; it's a free game, so worst-case scenario, you can simply remove it if you don't enjoy it. But if you do, you'll have hours, days, weeks or more of enjoyment. You'll make friends, get some kick-♥♥♥ looking gear (much of which has been made by the community) and probably forget what time it is.

Update July 17, 2015: I have logged on and played several times since I wrote my update on the morning of July 16 with minimal to no wait times. Now, at 9:24a central time, I get a 1000+ queue position, but an estimated wait time of 6 minutes. Not too bad, I suppose, providing the wait time is accurate. I'm letting it continue while I'm typing this. And at almost exactly 6 minutes, I'm in.  Now that I've put some time into playing, and not just queues, this is an entertaining variation on the voxel based genre that Minecraft popularized. A little bit of RPG with the suvive and dig and build. Persistent building on your cornerstone, which is a 16x16 area that stretches from the bottom of the world to the build limit, I believe, and can be 'teleported' to any vacant cornerstone plot in any world. Different levels of sub-worlds scale the difficulty, and hub worlds which provide some community services and a safe area. Club worlds which are also persistent builds, but are not publically accessible unless someone with the necessary level of control opens it up to public access (not sure exactly how this works, haven't played with it much, at this point). Mulitple classes with varying abilities. A wide variety of equipment with a wide variety of stats and modifiers. I still feel like I'm just scratching the surface, but I think it's worth a look if you like the voxel world genre.  Update July 16, 2015: First time with something other than '1000+' queue order. 800 something, and relatively quickly went down. Estimated wait time said less than a minute, but I think it was a bit more than a minute. Still, it's better than 20 minuites, and definitely better than 580 minutes. I don't know whether it was the server update, or people just getting fed up with the queue times. I did actually get some gameplay in, and it is an engaging game. I'm going to see how the queue times stack up for the next few days.  Update July 15, 2015: 580 minute queue time.  July 14, 2015: At this point in time, all I've seen are queue times ranging from 20 minutes to 200 minutes the few times I've tried to play. I can't recommend something like this. I frequently have limited time to play games, I'm not going to spend it sitting in a queue. I'll keep trying to get some actual gameplay time, but until I do, it looks awesome, but I can't recommend it unless you've got the time and patience to wait for it.

Trove is an exceptional MMO built around clever combat mechanics and smooth, Minecraft-like building. It's really easy to connect with your friends, and there's a cool learning curve to the game. All the enemies are unique, and the higher level dungeons require teamwork and strategy.  None of this counts for anything, however, if you can't play the game.   The game is new, but that's it's only defense. They made the same mistake they did with ArchAge, and didn't prepare for so many people to play it. It's constantly offline for hotfixes, the queue times can reach 10 minutes to 10 hours, and the game crashes and disconnects very often. Overall, I'd give this game an 8/10, and if it becomes more playable, 9/10.

I have played the game since early beta, and honestly it is what most people wanted from another product called: Cube World. The real benefit is it has grinding elements, with a levelling system up to level 20. The grinding isn't that bad, so for the more casual player it won't be like say, Diablo 3. But there is still a grind to get gear. The skills are very simple, one passive, and three skills. One skill is your M2, the 1 key, and your ultimate the 2 key. It is reasonably basic, and let's you get involved with the game sooner.   The economy is... Strange, it tends to be wonky and change rapidly with updates(Like most games). Most things in the shop can be bought with a currency called 'Cubits'(These are completely seperate from the unofficial currency of Flux and can NOT be traded.). You earn these every day from a daily system, you do enough dungeons and it gives you 500 on weekdays and 1000 on weekends. You also get them from a tutorial system, a few thousand at least to help you out. Potions are probably the only p2wish part of the game, considering that you need to earn the cubits in order to get the emblems for the potions to add addition effects, but the health regained is the game.  Classes are earned through this same Cubits system, and each cost about 5,000, with the newer classes being 8,000. Each class is unique, with some being tankier than others, and others being complete glass cannons that rely on not being hit to deal enormous damage. That being said, there are some cons to the game. Being a smaller game before Steam, the servers aren't the best. Right now they are working on getting more of them into the game, and working on optimizing the game, so it's a bit crashy and laggy at this time. It is also run off of another client called Glyph, some of you may remember a game called Archeage(Ironically having a bit of the same launch). However it DOES retain the things that steam offers, such as saying you are playing trove, and also giving you that delicious, delicious overlay that steam offers.  All in all, it kicks the pants out of most F2P games at this point, totally free to play. You don't need to buy ANYTHING in the game to progress at any point, it's a pay to progress faster game.

From a publisher that release an MMO that fail to live up to the hype (Archeage), MMO that based on sci-fi series that nobody really watch (Defiance), and MMO that noone really cares (Rift), comes a voxel MMO that surprisingly, a cool game. *read it with Honest Trailer voice*  Been playing this since beta on Glyph (in fact, I install this on Steam only to give review) and I really love it.  If you're looking for Voxel MMORPG that isn't dead, search no more!  Pros:  - tons of equipments! - break equipments for its skin (you can use sword A with skin from sword B) - With that feature above, costumization possibilities is limitless. - collecting items never been this fun! - Majority of items and equipments you will find is community made. Yes, that means you can make one, submit it on trove subreddit, if the dev thinks your creation is cool, they will put it in game. - Dungeons and lairs are also community made. - Double jump? pfft. How about 15x jump? - lots of classes. - Build your own house, find furniture recipes, create your dream house. Your house isn't stuck in one place. All over the world, there are many 'cornerstones'. When you saw an empty one, you press E on the sign, and your house is moving to your new cornerstone. Very convenient feature, really. You can play 24 hours without needing to go back to the hub. - Many biomes. Each biomes has loots that matching the theme of the biome (example, in desert biome, you'll more likely seeing wild wild west themed loot, in icy region, you'll find ice themed loot, etc)  Cons - As for now, queue times. - Sometimes, the grindfest is unbearable. - Some enemy are just reskin of another biome. - End game content needs to be more interesting.

Due to the sudden, immense popularity, the dev team is struggling to upgrade servers in order to accommodate everyone trying to log on, which makes me chuckle at all of the negative reviews due to the queue.   The game is really fun, once you get in. Simple mechanics, controls, and theme give this game a huge thumbs up in my book because it gives the game a 'let me just log on and go crush some mobs for a bit to find some random pieces of loot for a couple of minutes' and then you realize 3 hours passed while you were scouring the changing landscape, searching for more mobs to kill and loot to find.  There's also a crafting system, which I haven't gotten too deep into yet, but it looks fairly straight forward, which gives it the Minecraft feel. Instead of having hundreds of specific blocks, they made the landscape out of Primal Blocks of each color, so there's no searching for sandstone or oak wood or whatever you do in Minecraft these days. There're special ores and other crystal/shard/soul blocks that are needed for certain patterns, but they're easily found throughout the world.  All in all, 8/10 G_G devs, you made a game that filled the void in my heart that Cubeworld left by not being updated in over a year.

Trove is a very decent game. I honestly hated it when it was in Alpha, it was boring, had little content (which I expected from alpha) and there only 3 classes I am fairly sure.  DISCLAIMER: I will not be ranting about queue times, as it's not a very big deal. Reviews are reviews for the games GAMEPLAY, not server complications that will be fixed a few weeks after launch. It is wrong to review a game based on how stable it is the first week of it's launch. The devs do not know what can happen.  Most of that has changed, and for the better.  Trove really encourages and reward both creativity and exploration, and gives you many ways to build and explore in all the different worlds that are in fact, randomly generated by players as they create new worlds.  Creativity: Trove provides many ways for players to show how creative they are, including, -Cornerstones where you can build in a small area and freely move them around while exploring. -Club (Guild) worlds where you can build anything you want as big as you want it. -Can turn primal blocks into almost any color. (Once you find the recipes) -Not sure if this was limited to Alpha founders packs, but most equipment in the game was made by players. -Many cosmetic options to make your character look the way you want them to.  Exploration: Trove allows players with a mind for progression dig in on a feast, -Large amounts of loot to collect. -Dungeons are found almost everywhere; there is no shortage of things to fight. -There are many difficulty tiers that you will not reach the end of for a long time. -LOTS of classes that will fit different roles and playstyles. -Many biomes in the world to explore.  Cons: -A fair bit unoptimized, but it was even worse in alpha. -Starts to feel a bit grindy after playing for 5 hours straight. -No party system in a modern MMO? Okay then. -A community filled with 10 year olds and illiterate trolls  All in all Trove is a very fun game. I highly suggest you play it if you like the freedom that Trove provides.
