Ok this isn't my style to do reviews so sorry if I miss a few key points or leave some stuff out. Trove is a minecraft like game with a huge focus taken away from survival and more towards battleing monsters, clearing dungeons, and working together. At the time of writing this, there are 11 very different classes of warriors to choose from. To make it easier to pick out the good and the bad here, these are the pros and cons I have found so far:  Pros: Huge worlds to explore- When I say huge I really mean huge, as if each world is the size of a continent. Lots of loot- I have never come across two items with the same stats besides items you craft, which leads to the next pro. Craft a wide variety of items and blocks- These help you progress even further into the many world of Trove OR help you work together with friends to build eachother up. Shared Loot- The loot you see is yours to take, and any blocks or dropped items in a pretty ample area of your warrior are duplicated and given to each person close enough to recieve them. Someone mines 5 blocks and there are 4 people close by, 25 blocks are distributed evenly to the players so each recieve the full amount, and this is another big reason to play in large groups. Class changes- Most games with different classes require you to have a seperate character for each class. Trove gives you full access to EACH CLASS as you unlock them. Want to switch to your knight? Go to the world spawn point or if you crafted a class change block at your home and change, it is that easy. Mobile Home (so to speak)- Your home, called a Cornerstone, can be relocated seamlessly to any available plot in any world your in. Want to store items in your chests at your Cornerstone but its far away, its much closer than you think. Find an empty plot, claim it, and there you go your Cornerstone is right in front of you in a matter of seconds. No cost to relocate, no penalty, no cooldown, your home goes with you so long as you find a plot to summon it.  Cons Queue time- This is the one true con that I dont like to see. Queue times of over half an hour just to get in game. HOLD IT, before you stop reading and say 'I can't wait half an hour to play.' hear me out. This 30 minute wait is only temporary and isn't consistant. It is entirely possible to do something else while you are waiting. Watch something on Youtube or grab a quick bite to eat, or better yet anticipate when you want to play and start the queue early. It is worth the wait, trust me. Now to less crucial con I found. What am I doing?- There are some concepts that aren't explained in the tutorial/missions that can confuse newcomers. My example of this was buying a new class at the store (which is accessible anywhere as well with the press of a button). I bought a new class and it changed me to the class but I was lost. Do i have to start over now, I can't use any of the loot in my inventory because its too high level now. While this can be frustrating just use your head or reach out in the chat. Because I felt the confusion that new players are in I always respond to questions whenever I see them. Trove is about teamwork so don't be afraid to ask for help.  This sums up my experience of Trove. It is a DEVELOPING GAME, so don't be so hard on the dev team just because they didn't anticipate Trove becoming so popular. They are human, not fortunetellers. Also, Trove is Free to Play so what do you have to lose? What are you waiting for, get into Trove and GO EXPLORE.

The thing that keeps me playing Trove is how easy it is to gather a group and go co-op mode.  I made a club, and any time someone asked to be invited to a club over the general chat channel I immediately invited them. Since the game offers a quest which rewards joining a club early in the experience, players are always asking. Within a few days the club has grown big enough that there are always clubmates online, so I never have to run solo if I don't want to. Alternately, you can enter a certain chat channel by typing '/join adventure' which exists for people to coordinate and party up. Just decribe what you want to do in that channel and generally a player or two will ask to join you.  The game makes it easy to cooperate with other players by permitting instant teleportation to any friend or clubmate, and players can also invite others to join them for specific encounters, notably the shadow arenas.  The only complaint I have at this point (since we can certainly expect the queue times will continue to decrease untill they are gone entirely) is that the fast paced dungeon runs of a typical Trove party can leave a player behind if they enter chat to try to communicate. I hope we will see a VOIP feature or a Teamspeak server or something to allow more rapid communication.  Actually, I will add another thought to this wishlist. It can be hard to move in large groups, say four or more, because there can only be eight players on a world at a given time. That means that even if I and my friends want to join a clubmate to farm a specific resource, if the world is full we won't be able to join it. I'd like to see a way for groups of four to eight people to be able to move from world to world as a party.  Anyway, Trove is only getting started. I'm looking forward to seeing what awesome stuff the devs- and the community content creators- will come up with next.

+Quick game to jump into to mess around  +Has a mix of things to do to keep entertained for a few hours  -Each class has 3 skills along with basic attack/no varity  -Art style isnt a steady flow  -Not much content to keep one immersed  Best word of advice when starting this game is to DO RESEARCH ON THE CLASSES; the game does a bad job of not explaning what each class does, bearly giving details about each skills you get, i got lucky when rolling the Dragon class and got good mileage out of it but i wanted to try another so i said ill go with the gun class and boy do i regret not looking it up, it is not a good class.  Since it looks like this game has been around more then a year, it feels to me like an early acess game with its lack of content. They have Professions and the only ones available are Gardening, Ringcrafting, and Fishing, which each are as they sound by there name and are ok but still feel lacking in someways.  Hard to say if i actually do recomend or not depends what a person is looking for, this game is a quick causal burn of a game that is best played with a good group of buddies, but after a few hours the game gets stale as there is not much to do after awhile,   When i first saw this game i dispised the art style, i really didnt like how little detail there was in the blocks around the world but if you look at your own characters hair there has more voxel resulotion, this put me off but i gave this game a fair chance and im glad i did since once you can get past the small imperfections of how it looks its not a bad game.

To be honest, I really thought this game was gonna be really terrible and be a pay to win, however I was wrong. Very wrong. This is a very good MMO and has a good feel to the game. It's updated constantly, has balanced classes, doesn't shove a pay wall down your throat and it is truly a remarkable game. For those who think it looks bad, it really isn't. It allows the players to submit their own weapons (and soon bosses) into the game so the content never stops or gets repetitive. It has a Borderlands style loot which makes it so u don't always get the same weapon and if you do, it's witg different stats. This is an amazing game and this is the first review I've ever done, and this game deserves it.

I was kind of sceptical before downloading this game since it just looked like another Minecraft rip off. After downloading it, I realized it is WAY more than a Minecraft clone. There are dungeons that you can raid, to get items. And don't even get me started on the ammount of loot there is in the game. I would say there is upward of at least 1500+ loot items in game. It's one of those games you start playing and just can't stop. The feeling after killing a boss and wondering what he will drop is uncomparable. And the blocky Minecraft-esc style means that even people with low end computers can run this game at 30 FPS or more. The best part of the whole thing, is that the developers are still adding more to it. Only problem you will have with this game, is the social life you will lose.

Remember Minecraft? Well dont...   This game has a little of everything, from the first day it cought my attenction. We have character customization (hats, masks, weapons), character classes (Tomb Raiser, Candy Barbarian, Dracolyte to name a few) that fit different playing styles (mages, gun, swords), we have ground mounts (horses, cats, dogs), trail mounts (flying board,carts), water mounts (all boats right now), and wings (fire, darkness, styles!).  -It's all about getting stronger and for doing that you have fun, kill things and explore, the more you grow the more you get to do.   -Upgrading Systems for armor and weapons and character levels are only till lv20 however to get past that is by leveling your equipment.  -You get your own mobil home! (nothing like it sounds!) Throughout the world there are available plots to be temporarily occupied by players, but dont worry you keep whatever you made inside your plot to move anywhere in the world! Once you occupy a plot you can create which ever architecture you like, however it has to be within the vertical tower like shape of the plot, which goes from pretty deep down to the skies! -should see what people make-  -It is great for friends as more people together it is easier to get through the goals and dungeons, however never be shy of adding as many people as possible because you can always teleport to them to aid on their adventures. -Yes you can be a loner-  With that said if you are a minecraft player who did not feel complete then come to Trove, you are here to stay! :)

Pros: -Least egregious ftp model I've seen for a very long time. -Simple but fun classes and combat  -A TON of stuff to collect  -Great time vampire -You can easily teleport to friends that you want to play with.  Cons: -Stupidly insane difficulty spike around Uber-2 (Only way to counteract this is to spend hours crafting higher level rings or grind up enough in game currency for new flask and emblems)  -Community is very young, do your self a favor and just ignore all chats. -Leveling slows to a halt around level 15 - The servers are just will randomly go down and then you'll be stuck in a 30 minute queue. -Performance is 'Eh' random FPS drops and if you turn down the graphics the game just looks horrid. If you can deal with that, the performance is just fine. -Ping is just beyond silly, I have a 125 down/12 up and I have a ping of over 300. -No proper party system.  Summary: Great game to waste time in, you can just load it up and turn off your brain for hours.  Be wary of the mobile game level of difficulty curve (if you've played any mobile game you'll know what I am talking about)

Good game.  Pros:  -Blocky yet smooth looking graphics which don't demand a powerful PC  -Good range of enemies makes what would be very repetitive gameplay fun  -Working as a team can be good (however it is not perfect - see the 'Cons') -Varied and simple character customization allows you to make your character look how you want  whilst keeping your stats (which are affected by what you wear) at the best they can be.  -Large worlds allow for endless exploring  -Getting resources to build your house/base is easy and your house can be moved by simply clicking on a new cornerstone.   Cons:  -QUEUES - I know the creators of the game weren't expecting so many players but they need to get better servers so that you don't have to wait a decade to get in game.  -Teamwork can be annoying as people will end up stealing each other's loot  -No PvP  -Clearing dungeons can get repetitive

Honestly, i have been playing htis game since closed beta. It is not a bad game to log on and have fun on after a long day. BUT with the influx of people the wait times are quite bad in the day, evenings and nights is no issue. They have been working on a fix but honestly you can only make a door so wide and if thousadns of people continue to rush through it every minute you will end up with wait times. Most bad reviews i see are those who dislike waiting, they have nothing bad other then wait times and such to say about the game so let me make a nice little pros and cons.  Pro ------------------------ Easy to learn Simple yet fun crafting system. Combat is quite polished. Ingame items are cool some times flat out wacky showing a fun sense of humor. Classes can be unlocked via log in bonuse (gold coins). Free updates almost monthly. -------------------------- Con --------------------------- Costume colors are locked behind money currency. Community is a bit toxic but thats every mmo now days. Server log in times (hopefully fixed soon) Game randomly crashes form time to time due to glyph launcher being crud. --------------------------- This is what i gathered as i watched the game grow, if you want a simple game to play while you relax then look in to trove. If you want a game that will become your full time mmo then i recomend finding something else but keep this for those days you do not feel like raiding and such.

I played in open beta, but downloaded it on steam just because. Trove is a minecraft that is free and WAY better than minecraft. You are put in a world full of monsters such as, skeletons, wasps, robots, fairies, and even desserts (yes, you can fight cakes, gummy works, ice cream cones, and pieces of chocolate. You run around increasing your level while attacking bosses in dungeons. But there are other things to do other than fighting, such as fishing, crafting, sailing, and other things. Trove has a bunch of classes to choose from, such as gunners, ninjas, ice mages, fire mages, and fairies. There is a downside to this, if you are going to stay a free player, you have to keep playing for a couple of days to unlock just 1 class. It can take more than a week just to get 1 class.   There are a couple of downsides to this game that makes this review into a negative one. You may have seen it around, but the queue. GOD ♥♥♥♥ING CHRIST. And the lag, its unbearable how much lag that game has. The only time you can really play is late at night, where the playerbase is low.  Other than that, its fun. Just be prepared for long waits and a lot og lag.

Bascially a RPG version of minecraft, you can still build, but until you get into a club or make your own, youre limited to your cornerstone, unless you want to risk building at random areas, but thats not a bad thing. Everytime you move your house, any change moves with you. The dungeons are pretty straight forward until you get later in the game, you wont have much of a challenge at first, but its a decent way to learn the mechanics. There are microtransactions in this game, but as far as I can tell you dont have to buy anything to make the game playable. Also being like minecraft, you can dig into the world, collecting blocks and ore, unless its a dungeon, then you cant do much to it. The equipment is interesting as well, depending on the area you are in, you get a certain style. All and all its really fun and if you want a minecraft alternative, with rpg elements, always being online, and basically free. I highly suggest this game.

Where as Minecraft is about exploration, survival, crafting, decorating and creating your own bulidings or art projects (and for some people programming and music projects), Trove is more about fighting, mini-dungeon crawling, player progression through weapons, clothing items, RPG leveling and LOOT. Crafting as more of an after thought. You do need to find materials to make items in the world as in Minecraft but it isn't really the feature that sticks out in my mind when you play this. Crafting is more or less the thing you do so you can get even more loot to upgrade your character instead of for survival and to make your time trying to exist in the game easier. In that way Trove is essentially Destiny with a Minecraft skin on top. You'll repeatedly do the same tasks and dive into the same but only slightly different dungeons over and over again so you can get your loot and upgrade your character. The loot you get is in itself random so every time you get an item or defeat a dungeon boss it's like gambling. I somehow struck 777 on the 'slots' during my time playing and got a super rare and expensive Tron Bike. Another way to put it is that this is a game that relies on Skinner Box to keep players hooked, where it apparently succeeds based on the number of people I've seen playing.  It's a nice game to waste a little time with, but for me it holds no redeeming value beyond that. I never got the feeling like I was being challenged or that I was progressing in anything beyond character progression with no story or really a point to what I was doing being made clear. That sounds like the same kind of criticism you could put for Minecraft but playing Minecraft has always been more like a 'Zen Garden' thing I like to do when I feel like it. It's something I do to keep me calm with moments of excitement thrown in. Trove throws all that Zen stuff out the window to focus only on pretty mediocre action mechanics and in doing that it loses all appeal to me.  If this game is going to be more action and loot oriented it could at LEAST have a story to it to keep me interested so I know what I'm fighting for like in every other dime a dozen online massively multiplayer online game they throw at you for free on the internet. It feels like I was just being set loose in a randomly generated block world simply to beat up monsters to get loot and do other things just to get more loot to upgrade my character. The game doesn't bother to tell you everything you need to know about your character's fighting abilites (it does most, but not all) or how to find the items you need around you and just EXPECTS the player to go to a Wiki. Minecraft pretty much expected players to go to a wiki, but Minecraft started from a single group of people's website as an in beta indie project that didn't reach a major release till much later. It was already widely known from many sources that you needed to use a Wiki for information. Trove was released as a full game on Steam with dedicated servers and as a complete project, not as a work in progress like Minecraft. It just pretentiously expects you to go to the Wiki right off the bat with no hint that you should even look at one.  If you're the kind of person who likes 'stuff' and getting 'stuff' is the main thing that keeps you interested in video games, then you'll like this game because 'stuff' and being important because you have more and better 'stuff' than the other person is the main point of this game. Otherwise, if you're looking for something really exciting with some amount of depth, with a small story or something calm to do, you may be better off looking elsewhere. Also, good luck if your friends are a higher level than you and more interested in this game than you because due to monster difficulty levels you can't join them without getting slaughtered. Joining you would probably be boring unless they make a new character that is around your level. Pretty much once they've sunk more time into this game than you, you'll probably never see them very often even though you're both playing at the same time.  Trove feels like a very very striped down flashier version of Minecraft to me that takes out all the things I enjoy to focus on the things I'm kind of ok with but don't really enjoy that much.  There's a reason this game is called Trove. As in Treasure Trove. It's all about the Loot which ironically will all be gone when they eventually stop supporting this game.  On the plus side when you get loot in the environment it can't be taken by the other people in your party. Every person gets their own loot.

The combat gameplay is fun and interesting in the beggining, however after several hours of playing it will seem repetative. The good thing with trove is the fact that this isn't just a grinding grade destroyer, but has many other options to choose from. You can build, similar to minecraft but slightly different, in your cornerstone (mobile house) or a club world (basiclly a guild). The club is, personally, my favorite part because you get to meet many different people, such as kids asking for a spare penta if I have one or those who are of your age or older that could help you out. (Btw no one will ever give you a free penta). When you get bored of the club activities or gain a high level you can mess around in the market which is, for me at least, interesting due to the changes of prices with the new releases. Overall this game is a load of fun and I would recommend this game to every age group possible.

I want to make this clear to everyone I love this game, but there is one thing that has yet to be resolved despite the fact that it has been a long standing issue. Glyph updating system is the enemy of Norton [blunt]. The Glyph's files are considered a serious threat by norton, the solution in the past was to whitelist the downloaded content of Glyph. This would work normally if you download the game trove off the internet, which requires you to go download a seperate file from Glyph to let you play it. Thus the file of Glyph Exists. BUT in regards to Steam the program isn't needed...is what i like to say but the program is downloaded through Steam .... Meaning the File needed to be Whitelisted doesn't exist on your computer but in Steam. So when trying to update Glyph a seperate program that's been saved in Steam will try to update.... then Norton kicks in and stops it causing a loop when click on Trove's Icon the Glyph update starts up and then is quickly brought down by norton... the process repeats [Explanation]. An old solution that i'm not sure if its gonna be implement is that Trion would send the Glyph update to Norton to be whitelisted and then Norton would send an update to Norton users.... I dunno why no one is doing it, its not my field of expertise unfortunately....  Thus, I highly advise the readers of this review to take this with a few grains of salt, since I know I don't have all the answers in regards to this...   What saddens me the most though is that i won't get to play the game... I won't get to try these adventures into the game further... I want to play... but i will wait until my subscription is over or ... go download Glyph from the site and hope it crosses over... The game is awesome, the incompatibility sucks!!!!!   I will now [RIP]

First seeing this game, I saw it as minecraft and roblox had a baby. Now with some decent hours on it... its more like it's own thing. It's quite an intriguing spin on the olden style F2P(Free 2/to play) MMO with classes, in game currency, and a CRAP TON of things to do. To really describe this game... kind of requires a glazed over walk though. It's a 3d building MMO, what did you expect?   It starts out with dungeon-ering about with your first pick of a class, whatever it may be of the doesens of classes to choose from. It really breaks down into ranged or melee, and it's obvious who is who in that respect. There mildly hidden Info icon that looks like a small green button usually in the bottom left corner, which is something you will need consistently. It tells you general info on the general play style and skill names of the class. With your class picked out... the rest for about 13 levels is lots and lots of dungeons. Once you get enough cubits from daily playtime, you should be able to buy something in the in game store. You could buy health potions, new classes, mounts, emblems, (Which are passive equipable buffs) and allies. (Which are equipable pets, also with buffs) Generally what you want to do is increase your overall level, or mastery levels. This is done by doing things such as leveling up the different characters, or classes, learning new recipes or finding new items. Much past that... its up to you to do what you want. There are specific areas you get certain things for crafting and so forth, but that is more of a side note, even though it's a large part of the game! There's gardening, ring crafting, rune forging, reforging, ya-da ya-da bla bla bla, you get the idea.  To cut the crap, the following are the bare essentials to know.  PROS: *Expansive, with the constant updates this is no visible end to the content within this game. AKA: LOTS of playtime, for FREE! *Easy to learn combat with some genuine difficulty sprinkled on top *Easy time killer... no... MURDERER game. Still for free! *Great sound track and unique graphics *Your general dungeon crawling home can be moved with the press of a button *The building mechanics in game are exceedingly expansive. *You can craft yourself an entire WORLD to build in and to share with your friends... with enough resource grinding ---If you really enjoy it, there is always the premium mounts, costumes, and inventory expansions, those being VERY USEFUL. You run out of inventory awful quick with all the different things in this game. CONS: *Very repetitive if played for more than an hour or so in one sitting *None of the alternate things to do are heavily encouraged, they are really side quests when compared to dungeon crawling. *Building is neigh non-existent in the normal world, seeing as whatever you build outside of your set house, seeing as anything you build outside of it can and will be destroyed. *Your created worlds don't have ores in them, or any wide range of biomes. Those you have to craft. Yes... CRAFT your world's biomes. *Server side issues like you wouldn't believe, they are bound to be fixed in a reasonable amount of time *It's in early access, so there is going to be no shortage of bugs, glitches, and crashes. Shocking. I would say this game needs a fair dosage of work.   BUT HEY! ITS FREE!! That means a thumbs up from me!

Okay, 20 hours in, i think nows a good time to write up a review! So let's get into it.  Pros:  Sandbox, some may call this minecraft, others, cubeworld, but overall, this is not that much a clone in all honesty, it has it's own sandbox elements that make it differ from the famous mojang creation, other then digging a hole and less then simple crafting.  Combat, This i usually don't find much in games like this, warframe and blackdesert sure! but a sandbox? nah... well i would be lieing if i continued the debate against it, this is'nt the best combat obviousely, but it's still pretty good! in a Cube world-sec sort of combat, but still keeping to it's own style (If that makes any sense, and if not, It's action combat, but surprisingly non clunky in my opinion).  Crafting, I'll admit, not the BEST, but you don't have to be the best to be good, and this catagorizes as such atleast. looking for blueprints CAN get tedious at times, but this is an exploration game, which brings me to-  Free roaming, this is a game with not one, but nearly infinite worlds, dungeons, ares, and this game is still getting updates, so we Might be able to expect more biomes some time in the next year (It's currently december of when i'm writing this).  Classes, this game has 14 claasses currently (Maybe 15, i may have miscounted after the cloromancer's release) and each one you can play, For free... yep, FREE, no pay to win here in classes, you want to play as a knight? go ahead! the mage? just which element? a rogue? sci fi or old days? i'm certain you get the idea here, the only thing you have to do after you decide to switch is buy (with earned in game currency or bought premium currency) the class you desire.  Customization, one of the best perks in any game for me, not required, but it's always great to see a good system! in this case, it's a little 'lackluster' in some cases, but in other's, a mask and hat system, wings, a pet (or buddy), and even the skin of you'r weapon, Again, no buy to customize either!  Homes and Clubs, a.k.a, you get a plot of land, that of which may be brought up with a picket sign, that of which are scattered all over the many maps of Trovia(?), and within that space, you build WHATEVER you want, both Up and down, dig and build up whatever! and as for the clubs? this is where you and some friends get a whole iseland to yourselves, for the same purpose! (just becareful who you invite into the club...)  Events, many games have these, in this ones case, it's for new items, seasonal, christmas, halloween, valintines day, the usual.  Player made content, yes, that's right, this game DOES infact have this, not like TF2 or warframe where most you have to pay for, you just go out, and Find them! like any form of in game loot!  Resources, you know how in vanilla minecraft, you only get ONE iron ingot from one iron ore? and only ONE person get's it? does this annoy you? Me too (For those who answered yes), this game, resources are NOT light weight as such, just one persons digs up the ore, and anyone near it get's 1-2 of the said ore! and i mean you could have like 10 poeple close by and they get a share! (Not sure if it's actually 10 people, but to the point, multiple people gain from the ore block's breaking, as long as they are close by.)  Stats, and this one i add just because, certain stats effect things like double jumps (Jump 16 times in the air!?), Run speed, health and energy regen, a few things you would expect and other's you would have never thought of! (Unless you've played older games like oblivion and morrowind, in terms of jump height and speed...)  now the Cons:  Cash store, it IS unfortunate that this rose does have some thorns, and there ARE some things that can only be bought with REAL money, not that much to make it anywhere NEAR a deal breaker, but still...  Now the Nuetrals:  The Graphics, my opinion? Could be better, but atleast it's no minecraft clone... unfortunately, some may it it as otherwise just a mmo version of Minecraft, But i'm not gonna ask for them to change it, especially considering that those who KNOW this game, KNOW that it's NOT just another minecraft/cubeworld clone.  Repeats, by this i mean, you can easily learn the lay out of dungeons, the patterns and movesets of enemies, ect, yes this game does have plenty of variety, but this can get a little too easy after a while.  Story, short description, there is no story, you get in, do the tutorial (1-4 minutes) and then do whatever you want, some may see this as good, others may say 'What's the point with no story?', overall, i don't mind, it's just up to the player as to what they want to do...  So this game i have to say, is pretty Good considering what it brings, as a blunt way of saying it, it's a game where you go killing things for some resources, dig up others, and build you'r way up, metaphorically and literally, to be whatever class, whatever house, castle, tower, guild, clan or whatever! trove is a Sandbox, and you and every other player is the one building whatever you want!
This game is fun, but it loses that initial burst of fun quickly.

Pros: - Unlike most of the MMOs that are free to play, this one isn't pay to pwn. It does get harder later on, but not nearly impossible to the point where you need to waste money. - Classes have interesting mechanics overall, some require more skill than others. - Extremly community based. - Community is friendly, you rarely find griefing fools in this game. - Cornerstone feature is really good, there's a TON of blocks and character costumization. - You can swap classes with one account and still keep most of your stats and items. - Club Worlds are amazing, later on it gets kinda Minecraft; people do compete to see whom builds the better Club World. - Easy to understand on crafting -- People usually help you on forums or ingame chat. - Being Mastery Level 300 the max where you can go, there's a lot to do in this game.  Cons: - Servers aren't good, lets be honest. - PvP needs a lot of tweaking; also because of servers being bad, you can't fully enjoy PvP. - It gets kinda repeatitive after hitting max level(charatcer level). - There are some unfixed bugs that might annoy you a little bit. - Not the best game for people who want to be recgonized/have some e-prestige/compete(competing in PvP matters, or having the best Club because how good they are in PvP) - There are no Club wars yet.

This is a blocky game with barely any rules at all. You are guided on what to do all the time and are never confused. You are never left alone as you can build things in your cornerstone(house)with friends or follow the main objectives and look towards being a higher level. You can also make clubs that gives you a power to make a separate world to play with friends. You can defeat dungeons by yourself or again, do it with friends. There is a friending system so it is easier to find your friends. Trove is a highly addicting game (to me) and i recommend that you should get it as it is free to play and you only need the Glyph application which will come with Trove so you can also play some other amazing games from Glyph which (i think) are free to play.Trove is simply (on my list) the best block game on Steam. My personal favourite blocky game outside of Steam would be Minecraft. Trove is fantastic.

This is a really awesome game. It is arguably like minecraft in the blocky look aspect, however building isn't as much of a priority here. This is more of the RPG MMO type of game. Its very family friendly and casual. Right now, as of 12/2/15 there are a lot of changes going on, like the battle arena. If you like a game that will host events, or once in a while give free items, you'll like trove. Also, you can spend real money on this game, however, a good thing about this game is: You don't have to spend money to be good at it, or get rare items. Last but not least, the plot system is amazing. When you're in a world and need your house, you can just go up to a plot area (They're everywhere) and claim it, and your house pops up.  However...  Past the 10th level you tend to have to grind for items and chests, etc.  There have been many complaints recently about the game being down for developement or maintenence, and it being hard to download. If you want to play this prepare to have to sign up for glyph, and to sign in when you want to play the game.   Also the lag may be a downer for some people. You can change this a bit by going into the video settings.  ~~ Overall I think this game is worth it for everyone, as long as their computer can handle it and they're willing to wait a bit before playing (For downloads, sign ups and e-mail verification) Once you get past those things this game is the best.

Long-time player of Trove here- around late 2014, so most of my hours are from before the Steam release, and despite having tons of hours of fun on Trove, I wouldn't recommend anyone play game at all. To keep it as short as possible, here's a few reasons off the top of my head about why I can't recommend Trove anymore:  - Classes are pretty much impossible to get without paying real money, while before they could be purchased after a couple weeks of spending an hour a day in the game. - Dragons, which are essentially exclusive items with 'stages' like allies and mounts that switch out every month or so, have gone through serious downgrades: while before you could unlock every stage easily by spending a couple hours playing every day, you can now only get *one* stage of dragons for far more work, or through buying dragons for premium currency. - The Trion staff are an absolute joke, especially their support teams. You can see more than enough evidence for this in the popular reviews. - Content has been progressively getting more and more sparse, and the first real update we've gotten in months is a paid, or at least completely pay to win, expansion. Seriously, just read through the Mantle of Power DLC and tell me that doesn't give people a HUGE advantage.  I'd keep going, but it's 10:30 PM for me and I'm way too tired to care about Trion's latest screwups. Stay away from this game. It'll only get worse before it dies for good.

I definitly enjoy this game.   The developpers made a good job in adding more late game content, with now max lvl at 30, introduction of power gems, stellar equipment, u9 worlds, Ultra mode Shadow tower. I feel like i can always play this game.  If you liked Minecraft, and you like mmorpg with farming, such as runescape, this is for you!  Many people dislike the pvp system, but I find myself to enjoy it! They balanced it but making everyone OP, so everyone one shot everyone. But you still gotta be the one dodging everything to win.  I also think this game is not Pay to win, but paying gives you a great advantage in grinding WAYYYY faster. If you are patient, wait for weekly bonus, make your money by minning and completing hourly quests, you will in the end be just the same as any paying member.  The different style of the item, the huge variety of mounts, the possibility of having 30 jumps, is what makes this game beautiful and unique.   Hope to see you guys in the global chat soon!

Trove, what a wonderful voxelated MMORPG. Well, it used to be.    This game is fun, i mean seriously fun. Me and my friends could sit for two days straight just playing Trove, trying to gather some resources for us to either sell and earn flux or for crafting, run through shadow towers and dungeons, lvling, farm for wings and much more. There's something in Trove that just pulls you in and makes you want to keep playing, even though it's a complete grindfest. I believe it is the playful and casual yet hardcore and time-consuming approach of the game.   I started playing with a couple of friends who immediately got stuck in it. At LAN-parties, the only games we played were Trove and some Csgo in between just to have a little break. I mean, we were seriously enjoying the game. Little did we know Trion were about to f*ck sh*t up.   Everything was great until Trion slowly patched some new things into the in-game store. For example classes now costing credits instead of giving you a choice to either buy it with cubits or credits. I was lucky enough to have played for so long i managed to get all the classes without having to pay a cent because Trion sh*t out class coins back then.    Mantle of power

I've been playing Trove quite a bit for quite a few months now, the time shows it, but I've slowed down in recent times and now the Developers have made up my mind for me. So I will transcribe my experience with Trion and Trove with this review. I DO NOT recommend anyone pick up and/or play this game unless you enjoy grinding for hours on end without really getting anywhere or you have some serious cash to drop on it. The entirety of the game has basically become P2W.  The Developers seem to care, but I'm under the impression it's an act because any time I make a post criticising them, they ban me on the forums, nor do they actually listen to the player suggestions/concerns. They keep you in the dark about most any and everything until everyone has gone completely scare-mongering everywhere. They are, as many have said before, incompetent. I don't dislike them as people, but they're playing accountant instead of developing a game.  Every patch we get more and more content locked behind paywalls or removed for free players entirely, and while I can put up with the grinding I CANNOT put up with more and more content being locked behind payment methods, not to mention their plethora of packs, one of which includes early access to a patch that doesn't do much for the fun of the game as much as it makes players want to buy more inventory space (gems and gem dust will take up most of your inventory, not even getting started on the boosters).  You'd think Trion would want to make more money properly, by listening to the players that actually care about the future of this game, but I'm not one of them anymore. There is no forseeable good future for this game anymore, it's the next Archeage. Which, speaking on ArcheAge, the gem system is just the good ole' regrade system minus the chance of the item being lost completely.  The lag is also ungodly. Rubberbanding and world generation taking forever galore. They stated they made improvements for MoP, they might've made some slight ones, but nothing noticeable was done to fix those issues, not completely their fault but they definitely have enough people still buying their ♥♥♥♥ to afford to take care of it.  I can't justify their gem packs that come with MoP early access, it's not much of an expansion to be worth purchasing a pack that includes early access to it unless you really want those boosters and items in it. Or any of their decisions with item mall items and other actions they have taken. Oh yeah, almost forget to mention the game is heavily reliant on RNG, as much as any other Trion game now.  Finally, the devs have a serious lack of communication and/or miscommunication causing uproars/ doomsdayers/ etc to cause a ruckus before they finally give us some small response that barely answers anything we've asked them.  Watch them ban me for making this review, it's what Trion is good at. I didn't want to have to write this review but I'm sick of being banned for speaking my mind and trying to push the game into a positive direction. I'm not wasting anymore time with it. I had fun at first, Trion, but you ruined it for me with your ♥♥♥♥ decisions, heavy-handed monetization, and squashing anyone who criticizes your decisions on the forums with a ban.

Ok, so Trove is a good game. Quite good for its kind, in fact. Is it P2W? No. You don't need real money for more classes. People sell class coins (the things you use to get classes) in the auction house. You unlock that by getting mastery lvl 10. Paying really doesn't give that much of a bonus. The best thing (and in my oppinion the only thing you should buy if you buy something is patron. The other stuff is really just Random Number Generated luck based stuff. (Also known as RNG or chance)     Now, here is where RNG comes into play. RNG can play a big part in this game. If you want the coolest items in the game, you rely on boxes and your luck. Now these items im talking about are by no means the best items in the game. However, if you are one of those lucky people, those items can give you nice bonuses.    Now, the grind. The most dreaded part for most players. Once you get to Uber-1, thats when you really notice the grind to start appearing. However, your luck can easily be raised by something called 'Magic Find'. This has a chance to raise the stat of a random item in one of the dungeon chests you just opened. Magic Find is a stat that can appear on gear, gems etc. Also, special items and pets can increase it. Patron will also give you a nice boost to magic find if you are willing to put a bit of money into the game.   Now, the 3 main currencies. (For new players that dont know, glim that you get for various stuff is maining only for water travel and fishing) Okay, now flux. You get flux for doing a lot of stuff. Deconstructing, selling, doing dungeons, etc. It is a grind for a lot of flux. However, early/mid game can usually get most of the flux by deconstructing and opening boxes. Now, flux is used for just about everything that is not in the credits & cubits store, which i will get to right now. Every day you will get 500 cubits if you just play a little. Cubits are used for various things in the store, some more usefull than others. Now, Credits. You will get very few of these from the regular game. You get most from paying money. Most the stuff that you buy with them though, as I said earlier, really just isnt worth your money.    Finally, my rating of the game. I give it a solid 8/10. There are some tweaks that need to be made, yet there are still constant patches, updates, and sales. Of course, there is that every Friday stream that can give you rewards. Now, excuse me, i have to go play some more Trove.

Okay I rated this game once negative because of its queue system that gladly got removed in the following updates, so I am gonna edit this and make a new review.  I love this game. It is open world like minecraft, with different randomly generated bioms with alot of dungeons to explore. Inside them you can find hats, masks, weapons and scripts. Cornerstones also give you the possibility to make a own home or base in that area. If you collect scripts, you can get new crafting recipes or blocks to use.   Pros: Really addicting Fun with friends NOT P2W Getting club worlds is really fun if you have some players to build in it. Active Community You can change the skins/models of items but still keep the stats Since there are alot of crafting recepes, you gonna play a long time to get the items. Frequent updates!   Cons: Like said above, this game is based on grinding for Items/materials. You gotta decide if thats a bad or good thing. There isn't a skilltree. The only way to change your stats is by collecting different loot and level up. Longer Sessions can get boring. Shadowtowers and shadowarenas are probably the only ways to actually use strategy and not simply holding the mouse button and spamming special attacks.   Overall: I love this game. New content gets in frequently and the developers listen to their community. If you wanna have a nice F2P MMORPG thats nots P2W, check it out! You have nothing to lose.

Ah, Trove. Such a simple concept, yet although it may seem boring, this is when it decieves you...  Trove is addictive. Not really much else to say on the topic. There is always that one part of you inside that makes you want to get that higher mastery level. As a result, you decide to just spend a bit of time on it to farm for some flux for when you next come online. Next thing you know, it's 5am and you're still playing.  The fact that this game is free also makes things much better. Yes, recently the Devs decided to make some things only purchasable from real cash, but these people need at least someway of making money from this game!  The fact that the game is open to practically all ages really makes this more fun. Especially if it means playing with friends. This fantastic game is noticed by casual players who like building huge structures to show off their creativity, to more competitive players who like to complete quests, dungeons and fight in PVP mode.  Sure sure, the game is not perfect. But (very almost ;P) no game is either. Sometimes maintenance can last a while, but it's always worth the wait. I've been playing Trove for a while now, and it's amazing to see all the dedication that goes into this masterpiece with each and every update. I admit, I recently haven't been playing it as much as I used to, but I still love to play this game occasionally whenever I have free time on my hands. Besides, this game has enticed me for so long!  Hmmm, how should I say. Perhaps this game is a mix between Minecraft and an MMO? I'm not too sure to be honest, how ever what I am sure about is that once you click that 'Download' button, you're in for a heck of a treat.

It's a great game, overall. I had a blast with my friends for about a month, then we just suddenly stopped playing. We played hours on end during the summer, it was great. The dungeons are really creative, too, and they always match the biome they're in. It's not pay to win AT ALL. The building is pretty fun and great, and you can make some pretty cool things. The fighting system is really active, too. I played as a neon ninja, and honestly, its a fragile class that requires strategy. It's pretty hard to use(and I sucked at it).  Like all games, it has it's flaws. For example, it got pretty repetitive after like a month or so of playing it. It lacks PvP support, but that could be coming soon. There's very few biomes, so it lacks a bit of variety.  All in all, it's a really nice game to get into. You can venture around and explore, restocking at your portable home(called a cornerstone). Club worlds are private worlds that you can make for your group(you can make them public if you want) and allow you to unleash your creativity. There's a lot of neat stuff to do in the game, but the dungeoneering will get repetetive and will eventually feel like it lacks in variety. It's a nice game, but you will most likely end up uninstalling it after a while because it'll get a bit boring.  Tl;dr A pretty good game. I do recommend a download, but it will get repetitive after a while of playing.  EDIT: I came back to this game after a while, and it went from free to play into pay for things that used to be basic features. The challenge in this game was completely removed, too, since you can get your wings at mastery rank 5 or near there. You used to have to go until 30.

Too much P2W. (Pay 2 Win) But, the game is fun. They just need to take away the basic P2W feature and maybe this game could earn a hell of a lot more recommendation instead of just straight disliking. Maybe even more money now that everything doesn't cost money and people would buy more instead of straight quitting the game because everything costs money. I wouldn't be suprised if just playing the game itself costed about $4.99 an hour. The dev team just needs to not be super greedy. By the way, if you played this game last year, not everything was you have to pay for it. Also, classes used to be a free currecny, called Cubits, but now they're only CREDITS witch you need to buy with real cash. Also, Cubits are even HARDER to earn now that the star bar gives less. There was no 'You need patron to get better daily awards.' last year either.

Great game concept, good visuals and great gameplay. Sadly as any other game Trove has its setbacks. Many times have I found myself grinding dungeon after dungeon, biome after biome just grinding my way to the top, just to come across a new player who just opened his/her first box and got the rarest drop. Understanding the massive gap in this game's RNG system is quite lucrative... if you're in the end-game. This is because you need to stack massive amounts of caches in order to even have a chance at those 'rarer' drops. This can be good, since it means that you have to work for the gear, but it divides the players from those who can afford the time and effort, and those who only have 2-5 hours a day, not counting the individual player's efficiency(how good a player can do the work in the fastest way possible). In the end, the game has good class/skill synergy and enough material to keep a player busy for a substantial amount of time, with even more content being added continuously. In my personal opinion, this game has a bright future with much more room for improvement.

I'd like to update my review because of a important thing that happened to my husbands account...  Someone was able to imitate our IP address, hack into his account, and they destroyed all the items in our club world chests while he was sleeping. Since the GMs couldn't prove this happened, they couldn't restore the lost items. This has made both of us very upset, naturally, and it was the last straw for him. This stuff didn't happen until the PVP update happened months ago, and the people he kept beating were retaliating back at him.   So, we both uninstalled the game, and will not be playing it again.   _____________________________________________________  I've been playing since November of 2014, as soon as this game came out of closed beta. I really enjoy this game, aside from the hourly challenges. The hourly challenge is like a mad zerg rush to finish as many dungeons as you can in a 20 minute timespan, to fill your 'Challenge Bar'. Upon completion of each level of the bar, you get a 'Dragon Cache' that has (as of this moment) 4 different prizes: Eyeballs, Flux, Dragon Coins or Penta-Forged Souls. All of those items are used for upgrading your gear. You need lots and lots of Flux and Eyes. The classes are good, except the Boomeranger. His boomerang does not always work like it's supposed too. I'm pretty sure it's a glitch/bug that has not been fixed yet. The Shadow Hunter does not do too much damage either, and the Current new class, the Tomb Raiser, is a little OP in my opinion. If you have the Death Defying Vial potion, then you can tank like nobody's business.  Aside from those little issues, there is a building aspect to this game, kind of like minecraft. You get your own personal plot of land called a Cornerstone that you can build on. These plots of land look like a big black square with a little yellow sign on the edge of the square. No matter where you build your home, you can summon it at one of the black platforms, in any land you go to (aside from the club worlds). You can also make your own clubs, or join a club that someone else made. You can have up to 5 clubs in your roster, and you can be the leader of more than one club. I currently have 3 clubs that I own, I joined my Husband's club, and I am in a random club that a single person is in. There are a bunch of different blocks you can build with, and some organic blocks that can add liquids (water, lava, chocolate) to your home/club. There are also musical blocks to play with. I suggest you check out the Trovian Maestroes club, or Voxel Busters. They have some awesome songs setup there. There is gardening you can do. Some plants are decorative, others grow materials that you use for crafting.  With the Club worlds, you can expand beyond the initial land you have by crafting Terraformers. They are not cheap to make, but they do add extra biomes you can bulid on. I think the maximum number of members a club can have is 750? I'm pretty sure. There is no adventuring in the club worlds, sadly enough. Just open spaces to see people pixel-art.  So, do I recommend this game? Yes. You can send me a friend request too. I play almost every afternoon. I do not mind the grinding for items, but some people might. I'm looking forward to the new class coming out, the Lunar Lancer, since I tried it out on the Player Test Realm. I'm also looking forward to the new Shadow Tower update.

Well let me start off by saying that this game was one of the best games that I have played. When I first started I had no idea behind what I was supposed to do, but it was a heck of a lot of fun. I enjoyed the constant dungeon raids and felt quite satisfied as I progressed through the game, getting stronger and stronger. I liked playing this grindy game with my friends, it was a blast. That was before gems were added to the game, and now that they are added, I feel like this game is more based off of RNG now. It can be hard to get gems that benefit your character, if you happen to be a class that deals physical damage, you'll probably get a million magic damage gems. Not only that, but you can't even buy other classes with the normal ingame currency anymore, instead you have to now use the premium currency. I'm not saying that players interested in this game shouldn't try it out, or saying that they should. If you want to play Trove, go for it! I still have fun with it, and I'm sure many others do aswell, it would just be nice if the devs made it so that there isn't as much pack and deal buying. Also fixing the PvP system would be nice.

'TLDR: A true Free-to-Play game...' Ooooh... this review pains me to look at now. if you want to hear why this game is bad nowdays, you can look at many others. I'm just going to stress that this is a prime example of why premium content exists.  Are the devs being asses? I dunno, but I do have a big suspision that they are lieing to us. With the sudden relese on other platforms and more and more 'pay for/to get/to unlock/to progress...' is being shoved in are faces is because  I believe Trion feels that Trove, for it's huge playerbase back in the before times, was not pulling in nearly enough profit to warent it existing. Now lower your pitchforks, I know nobody likes the P word when it comes to 'free2play'. Give me a chance to explain, if you would be so kind.  Lets talk about the afore mentioned before times. I, and I'm sure many other players, loved all the free stuff they got. Free dragon coins, free classes, free this, free that, work a little bit for this and that... So on, so forth. I, for one, never felt the need to buy things because they always seemed to be handed to me. Due to that, one the off chance I had money to spare while I'm slowly building up my life being freshly on my own, I never really considered Trove as the spot to spend what little spare change I had. Does this sound familier to any of you? Not even in a 'money's so tight' situation like mine. 'But I'm not like that!' Sure. I'm sure you and many others weren't. I'm sure at least five times as many were though. We like our dollars a lot.  Now of course I'm not talking about everyone, nor are the devs entierly blameless, but I do feel like, when my fellow vets look at how much of the cash shop content was also throwm right into their hands as an appology for an update, or an event, or as a log-in reward, or for so many other reasons, what would compel you to spend? I'm just your average gamer. I'm not hardcore, I'm not particularluy serious, and trove, while an amazing game, was behind a lot of other games I enjoy in my list of priorities. Now if I was, I could have been like my friend, who saved up 200 dragon coins over the course of a month long event without paying a cent by buying from others as well, who also got them for free from the same event, and got every new dragon to come out for a long frikken time.  Now again, the Devs deserve some blame. They could of handled this is so many other ways. They could of been less open-handed, they could of looked at warframe and took some tips from them and balanced fairness and convinence (and if retail and the music industry has taught me anything, people will pay out they ♥♥♥ for convinence) rather then having the free players throw their lives away to have a quarter of the fun, They could of had some advertisments or hosted some companys or bands for a month or two (big money, that), and I've seen stuff like that done in amazing ways. and guess what. I pulled all those answeres from off the top of my head.   I miss this game, I really do, and if this all works out in the end, I would love to come backm esspecially now that I'm more well off, but even then, I only offer my money to games I respect, and Trove? Even with all the wonderful memories, has lost mine.  I hope it makes a rebound before it gets a stigma as a bad game.
